subsection.content: Where a statement contained in a maintenance application indicates that a designated patent has been granted on a date within the 6 months before the date of the maintenance application, any maintenance of the standard patent (R) application by virtue of subsection (5) shall have effect for a term ending 6 months after the date of such grant.
If there are deficiencies in the maintenance application that may be corrected the Registrar shall give the applicant an opportunity to correct them in accordance with the rules.

If the Registrar is not satisfied as to the veracity of a statement in the maintenance application, he shall notify the applicant accordingly giving reasons and shall allow the applicant an opportunity to make further statements or adduce material for the purpose of so satisfying him.

subsection.leadIn: If in an application under this section—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: statements contained in the application indicate that—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: the designated patent application has been withdrawn or abandoned pursuant to the law of the designated patent office;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: the designated patent office has finally refused the grant of a patent in pursuance of the designated patent application; or

subparagraph.name: iii

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: deficiencies as noted by the Registrar are not corrected in accordance with the rules; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the applicant has failed to satisfy the Registrar as to the veracity of a statement in respect of which notice has been given under subsection (8),

subsection.continued: the Registrar shall refuse to maintain the standard patent (R) application and upon such refusal that application shall be deemed to be withdrawn or abandoned.

subsection.content: The Registrar may by regulation amend the period specified in subsection (2) by reference to which the earliest date for making a maintenance application under that subsection is determined.

The Chief Executive in Council may by regulation amend the period specified in subsection (2) as being the period after which a standard patent (R) application not maintained shall be deemed to be withdrawn and abandoned. (Amended 22 of 1999 s. 3)

section.name: s34
section.heading: Restoring application for standard patent (R)

subsection.content: Where an application for a standard patent (R) is deemed withdrawn under section 33 by reason only of the failure to pay any maintenance fee under that section within the period specified then the applicant may, within 12 months after the date on which the application was deemed withdrawn and on payment of the prescribed fee, apply to the Registrar in the prescribed manner for the restoration of the application for a standard patent (R). (Amended 17 of 2016 s. 41)
The Registrar shall advertise in the official journal notice of any application under subsection (1). (Amended 2 of 2001 s. 14)

subsection.leadIn: If on an application under subsection (1)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the Registrar is satisfied that the failure to pay the maintenance fee within the specified period, or that fee and any additional fee under section 33(4) within 6 months after the end of the specified period, occurred in spite of the applicant having taken all reasonable care required by the circumstances; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the requirements of subsection (4) are met,

subsection.continued: the Registrar shall order that the request to record be restored on payment of any such unpaid maintenance fee and additional fee.

subsection.leadIn: An order for restoration shall not be made under subsection (3) unless it appears to the Registrar that at the date of the application for restoration—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the designated patent application is still valid and not withdrawn; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a patent has not been granted in pursuance of that application or, if granted, the time for filing a request for registration and grant under section 23 has not expired.

section.name: s35
section.heading: Effect of restoration order under section 34

subsection.content: The effect of a restoration under section 34(4) is as follows.

subsection.leadIn: A person who, during the period between any deemed withdrawal such as is mentioned in section 34(1) and the advertisement in the official journal of notice of the application for restoration under section 34(2)— (Amended 2 of 2001 s. 14)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: does in good faith an act which would constitute an infringement of the applicant’s rights under the published application for a standard patent (R) if those rights had not been lost; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: makes in good faith effective and serious preparations to do such an act,

subsection.continued: has the rights specified in subsection (3).

subsection.leadIn: The rights referred to in subsection (2) are—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the right to continue to do or, as the case may be, to do the act referred to in subsection (2);

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: if such act was done or preparations had been made to do it in the course of a business—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.leadIn: in the case of an individual—

subparagraph.name: A
subparagraph.content: the right to assign the right to do it or to transmit such right on death; or

subparagraph.name: B
ii
subparagraph.content: in the case of a body corporate, the right to assign the right to do it or to transmit such right on the body’s dissolution,

subsection.continued: and the doing of that act by virtue of this subsection shall not amount to an infringement of the applicant’s rights under the published application for a standard patent (R) concerned.

subsection.content: The rights specified in subsection (3) shall not include the right to grant a licence to any person to do an act referred to in subsection (2).

Where a product is disposed of to another in exercise of a right conferred by subsection (3), that other and any person claiming through him may deal with the product in the same way as if it had been disposed of by the applicant of the standard patent (R) application.

This section applies in relation to the Government use of an invention in respect of which an application has been made as it applies in relation to infringement of the rights conferred by publication of an application for a standard patent (R) for the invention.

section.name: s36
section.heading: Limitation on withdrawal, amendment, etc. of application
section.content: No withdrawal of an application under section 32, no request to enter a record of a divisional application under section 22(1) nor any amendment under section 31 shall be allowed after the date on which preparations for publication under section 27(3) of the specification of a standard patent (R) to be granted in pursuance of the application have been completed.

section.name: s37
section.heading: Registrar may refuse to record under section 20 or to register and grant under section 27

subsection.content: The Registrar may refuse to record a designated patent application under section 20(1) or to register a designated patent under section 27 if he considers that the invention the subject of the application for the standard patent (R) is not a patentable invention by reason of any of the matters specified in section 9A(5). (Amended 17 of 2016 s. 44)
The Registrar shall give notice in writing to the applicant of any such refusal.

section.name: s37A
section.heading: Interpretation of Division 1 of Part 3
section.leadIn: In this Division—
section.def: Hong Kong application (香港申請) means a standard patent (O) application or short-term patent application;

non-Hong Kong application (非香港申請) means an application for a patent or other protection in or for a Paris Convention country or WTO member country, territory or area, other than a patent application under this Ordinance.

section.name: s37B
section.heading: Non-prejudicial disclosure

subsection.content: For the purposes of section 9B, if the conditions specified in subsection (2) are satisfied, a disclosure of an invention that is the subject of a standard patent (O) application is not to be taken into consideration in determining whether the invention forms part of the state of the art.

subsection.leadIn: The conditions are—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the disclosure occurred no earlier than 6 months before the date of filing of the standard patent (O) application; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: the disclosure was due to, or in consequence of—

subparagraph.content: an evident abuse in relation to the applicant or a proprietor of the invention for the time being; or

the fact that the applicant or a proprietor of the invention for the time being had displayed the invention at an official, or officially recognized, international exhibition falling within the terms of the Convention on International Exhibitions signed at Paris on 22 November 1928, as applied to Hong Kong.

subsection.leadIn: Subsection (2)(b)(ii) applies only if the standard patent (O) application as filed contains—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a statement to the effect that the invention had been so displayed; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the prescribed written evidence in support of the statement.

section.name: s37C
section.heading: Priority right

subsection.leadIn: Subsection (2) applies if a person has filed—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a non-Hong Kong application for an invention; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a Hong Kong application for an invention.

subsection.content: The person or the person’s successor in title enjoys, for the purpose of filing a subsequent standard patent (O) application for the same invention, a right of priority for the period of 12 months after the date of filing of the first non-Hong Kong application or Hong Kong application, subject to compliance with the prescribed conditions.

subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of subsection (2)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: every filing of a non-Hong Kong application that is equivalent to a regular national filing under the domestic legislation of the place in or for which the application is filed, or under bilateral or multilateral agreements, is to be recognized as giving rise to a right of priority;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: a subsequent non-Hong Kong application for the same subject-matter as in a previous first non-Hong Kong application and filed in or for the same place is to be considered as the first application for the purpose of determining priority only if, on the date of filing the subsequent application, the previous application—

subparagraph.content: has been withdrawn, abandoned or refused, without being open to public inspection and without leaving any rights outstanding; and
has not served as a basis for claiming a right of priority; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: if, because of paragraph (b), a subsequent non-Hong Kong application is considered as the first application, the previous non-Hong Kong application may not later serve as a basis for claiming a right of priority.

subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of subsection (2)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: every regular filing of a Hong Kong application is to be recognized as giving rise to a right of priority;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: a subsequent Hong Kong application for the same subject-matter as in a previous first Hong Kong application is to be considered as the first application for the purpose of determining priority only if, on the date of filing the subsequent application, the previous application—

subparagraph.content: has been withdrawn, abandoned or refused, without being open to public inspection and without leaving any rights outstanding; and
has not served as a basis for claiming a right of priority; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: if, because of paragraph (b), a subsequent Hong Kong application is considered as the first application, the previous Hong Kong application may not later serve as a basis for claiming a right of priority.

subsection.content: A right of priority that arises as a result of a non-Hong Kong application or Hong Kong application for an invention may be assigned or otherwise transmitted, either with the application or independently, and the reference in subsection (2) to a person’s successor in title is to be construed accordingly.

subsection.leadIn: In this section—
subsection.def: regular national filing (正規國家提交) means a filing that establishes the date on which an application was filed, whatever the outcome of the application may be.

section.name: s37D
section.heading: Restoration of priority right

subsection.leadIn: This section applies if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a person files a non-Hong Kong application or Hong Kong application for an invention; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the person or the person’s successor in title files a subsequent standard patent (O) application for the same invention within 2 months after the expiry of the 12-month period referred to in section 37C(2).

subsection.content: The applicant of the subsequent standard patent (O) application may apply to the Registrar for restoring the priority right of the patent application.

subsection.leadIn: The application for restoring the priority right (restoration application) must be made in the prescribed manner before the earlier of the following—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the end of 2 months after the expiry of the 12-month period;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the date on which preparations for publication under section 37Q of the subsequent standard patent (O) application are completed.

subsection.content: A restoration application is to be regarded as being made only if the prescribed fee for the application is paid.

The Registrar may approve a restoration application if the Registrar is satisfied that the applicant failed to file the subsequent standard patent (O) application within the 12-month period even though the applicant had taken all reasonable care required by the circumstances.

section.name: s37E
section.heading: Claiming priority

subsection.content: An applicant for a standard patent (O) desiring to take advantage of the priority of a previous application must file, in the prescribed manner and within the prescribed time, a statement of priority and a copy of the previous application.

subsection.leadIn: Multiple priorities, whether or not they originated in different countries, may be claimed—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in respect of a standard patent (O) application; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if appropriate, for any one claim in the application.

subsection.content: If multiple priorities are claimed, a time limit that runs from the date of priority is to run from the earliest date of priority.

If one or more priorities are claimed in respect of a standard patent (O) application, the right of priority is to cover only those elements of the application that are included in the previous application or applications the priority of which is claimed.

Although certain elements of the invention for which priority is claimed do not appear among the claims formulated in the previous application, priority may still be granted if the documents of the previous application as a whole specifically disclosed the elements.

section.name: s37F
section.heading: Effect of priority right

subsection.content: The right of priority conferred by section 37C has the effect that the date of priority of a previous application claimed under section 37E is to be regarded as the date of priority of the standard patent (O) application for the purposes of this Ordinance.

subsection.leadIn: If—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a standard patent (O) application is filed; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the priority of a previous application is claimed under section 37E,

subsection.continued: then despite anything contained in this Ordinance, the standard patent (O) application, and the standard patent (O) granted because of it, are not to be invalidated only because any subject-matter disclosed in the previous application was made available to the public at any time after the date of filing of the previous application.

division.name: D2
division.heading: Who may Apply for Standard Patent (O)

section.name: s37G
section.heading: Application may be made alone or jointly

subsection.content: An application for a standard patent (O) for an invention may be made by a person alone or jointly with any other person.

Subject to any determination under section 37H, for the purpose of proceedings before the Registrar, the applicant is to be regarded as being entitled to apply for a standard patent (O) for the invention.

section.name: s37H
section.heading: Determination before grant of questions as to who may apply

subsection.leadIn: At any time before a standard patent (O) has been granted for an invention—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: whether or not a standard patent (O) application for the invention has been filed, a person may refer to the Registrar or the court the question whether the person is entitled, whether alone or jointly with any other person, to apply for a standard patent (O) for the invention; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if such an application has been filed, any of the joint proprietors of the application may refer to the Registrar or the court the question whether any right in or under the application should be transferred or granted to any other person.

subsection.content: The Registrar or the court may make an order that the Registrar or the court thinks fit to give effect to a determination on the question referred.

section.name: s37I
section.heading: Powers of Registrar and court if standard patent (O) application has been filed

subsection.leadIn: Without limiting section 37H(2), if a question is referred to the Registrar or the court under section 37H(1) after a standard patent (O) application has been filed—

paragraph.name: a
b
paragraph.content: the Registrar or the court may order that, because of the reference, the standard patent (O) must not be granted;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the Registrar or the court may order the application to be amended, subject to section 103(2), so as to exclude any matter to which the question relates; or

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.leadIn: the Registrar or the court may—

subparagraph.content: make an order transferring or granting a licence or other right in or under the application; and
give directions to any person for carrying out the provisions of the order.

subsection.leadIn: No order may be made under subsection (1) unless notice of the reference is given in the prescribed manner to each person who, not being a party to the reference, is—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: an applicant named in the standard patent (O) application; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: a person alleged in the reference to have the right to apply for a standard patent (O) for the invention, whether alone or jointly with any other person, because of any transaction, instrument or event relating to—

subparagraph.content: the invention; or
the standard patent (O) application.

subsection.content: A person who receives a notice under subsection (2) may oppose the making of the order, which is sought in the reference.

If a person (person A) to whom directions have been given under subsection (1)(d)(ii) fails to do anything necessary for carrying out the directions within 14 days after the date of the directions, the Registrar or the court may, on application by a person (person B) in whose favour or on whose reference the directions have been given, authorize person B to do the thing on behalf of person A.

No direction is to be given under this section so as to affect the mutual rights or obligations of trustees or of the personal representatives of deceased persons, or their rights or obligations as such.

section.name: s37J
section.heading: Registrar and court may order new standard patent (O) application under certain circumstances

subsection.leadIn: This section applies if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a question is referred to the Registrar or the court under section 37H(1)(a) after a standard patent (O) application (earlier application) has been filed; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: the earlier application—

subparagraph.content: is refused according to an order under section 37I(1)(b);
is refused under any other provision of this Ordinance, or is withdrawn, before the Registrar or the court has disposed of the reference.

subsection.leadIn: The Registrar or the court may make an order providing—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: that a person who made the reference may, within the time specified in the order and subject to section 103(1), make a new standard patent (O) application for—

subparagraph.content: all or any of the matters comprised in the earlier application; or
if applicable, all or any of the matters excluded from the earlier application;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: that the date of filing of the earlier application is to be regarded as the date of filing of the new application; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: that the new application enjoys the benefit of any right of priority.

section.name: s37K
section.heading: Effect of transfer of application on licences and other rights in or under application etc.

subsection.leadIn: If an order is made under section 37I that a standard patent (O) application must proceed in the name of any original applicant (whether or not the application is also to proceed in the name of some other person), a licence or other right in or under the application is, subject to the order and any directions under section 37I(1)(d)(ii)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: to continue in force; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: to be treated as granted by the person in whose name the application is to proceed.

subsection.leadIn: If an order is made under section 37I that a standard patent (O) application must not proceed in the name of any original applicant, but must proceed in the name of another person (on the ground that the original applicant was not entitled to apply for the patent), a licence or other right in or under the application is, subject to the order and any directions under section 37I(1)(d)(ii), to lapse—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: on the registration of the other person as the new applicant; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if the application has not been published, on the making of the order.

subsection.content: If an order referred to in subsection (2) is made, an original applicant of the standard patent (O) application or a licensee of the applicant who meets the conditions specified in subsection (5) is entitled to be granted a licence by the new applicant to continue working or to work, as the case may be, the invention which is the subject of the application.

If a new standard patent (O) application is made in accordance with an order under section 37J(2), an applicant of the earlier application or a licensee of the applicant who meets the conditions specified in subsection (5) is entitled to be granted a licence by the applicant of the new application to continue working or to work, as the case may be, the invention, so far as it is the subject of the new application.

subsection.leadIn: The conditions are—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: the applicant or licensee, acting in good faith before the reference that results in the making of the order—

subparagraph.content: worked the invention in Hong Kong; or
made effective and serious preparations to do so; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the applicant or licensee makes a request for licence to the new applicant or applicant of the new application, as the case may be, within the prescribed time.

subsection.leadIn: A licence granted under subsection (3) or (4)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: is a non-exclusive licence; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: must be granted for a reasonable period and on reasonable terms.

subsection.leadIn: A person to whom a request for licence is made, or a person claiming to be entitled to be granted a licence, may refer to the Registrar or the court the question—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: whether the latter is so entitled; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: whether the period or terms of the licence are reasonable.

subsection.leadIn: On a reference under subsection (7), the Registrar or the court—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: must determine the question; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: may make an order that the Registrar or the court thinks fit to give effect to the determination, including an order for the grant of a licence.

section.name: s37L
section.heading: Requirements of standard patent (O) application

subsection.leadIn: A standard patent (O) application must—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: be signed by the applicant; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: be filed with the Registrar in the prescribed manner.

subsection.leadIn: A standard patent (O) application must contain—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a request for the grant of a standard patent (O);

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: a specification that provides for—

subparagraph.content: a description of the invention which is the subject of the application;
at least one claim; and
any drawing referred to in the description or the claim or claims;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: an abstract;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: if the applicant desires to claim non-prejudicial disclosure of the invention under section 37B(2)(b)(ii), the statement and evidence required under section 37B(3);

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: if the applicant desires to take advantage of the priority of a previous application, a statement of priority and a copy of the previous application required under section 37E(1); and

paragraph.name: f

subsection.leadIn: A standard patent (O) application—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: must state the name and address of the applicant;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: must—

subparagraph.content: identify each inventor of the invention; and
specify the last known address of each inventor (unless the inventor is also the applicant);

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: if the applicant is not an inventor, must contain a statement in the specified form indicating how the applicant becomes entitled to apply for a standard patent (O) for the invention; and

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: must specify an address in Hong Kong for service of documents.

subsection.content: A standard patent (O) application must also comply with the requirements of this Ordinance on providing information in, or translating documents into, one or both official languages.
A filing fee and an advertisement fee are payable within the prescribed time.
If any of the fees is not paid within the prescribed time or the grace period provided in the rules, the application is to be regarded as being withdrawn.

subsection.leadIn: The rules may—

paragraph.name: a
b
paragraph.content: provide for the requirements of a standard patent (O) application for an invention that involves nucleotide and amino acid sequences.

subsection.content: This section does not prevent a standard patent (O) application from being initiated by documents complying with section 37M(3).

section.name: s37M
section.heading: Date of filing of standard patent (O) application

subsection.leadIn: For the purpose of according a date of filing to a standard patent (O) application, the Registrar must examine the application to ascertain—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: whether it complies with the requirement specified in subsection (3) (minimum requirement); and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: whether the prescribed filing fee and advertisement fee have been paid within the prescribed time.

subsection.content: Subject to section 37N(3), the date of filing of a standard patent (O) application is the earliest date on which the application complies with the minimum requirement.

subsection.leadIn: The requirement specified for subsection (1)(a) is that the documents filed for the standard patent (O) application contain—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: an indication that a standard patent (O) is sought;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: information identifying the applicant; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.leadIn: either one of the following—

subparagraph.content: something that appears to be a description of an invention;

a reference to an earlier specified application made by the applicant or the applicant’s predecessor in title, together with a statement indicating that a description and the drawings (if any) of the invention, which is the subject of the standard patent (O) application, are completely contained in the specified application.

subsection.content: If a date of filing cannot be accorded to a standard patent (O) application because of deficiencies in the application as regards the minimum requirement, the Registrar must give the applicant an opportunity to correct them in accordance with the rules.
If any deficiencies referred to in subsection (4) are not corrected within the prescribed time, the application must not be dealt with as an application for a standard patent (O).

subsection.leadIn: In subsection (3)(c)(ii)—

def.name: SpecifiedApplication
def.leadIn: specified application (指明申請) means—

paragraph.name: a
b
paragraph.content: a standard patent (O) application; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: a short-term patent application.

section.name: s37N
section.heading: Filing of missing description or missing drawing

subsection.content: The Registrar may, by written notice, require the applicant of a standard patent (O) application to file a missing description or missing drawing in the prescribed manner and within the prescribed time.
The applicant may also, on the applicant’s own initiative, file a missing description or missing drawing in the prescribed manner and within the prescribed time.

If the standard patent (O) application has been accorded a date of filing in accordance with section 37M(2), then on the filing of a missing description or missing drawing, the date of filing is to be changed to the date on which the description or drawing is filed.
The Registrar must, by written notice, inform the applicant of the change of the date of filing.

subsection.leadIn: Subsection (3) does not apply if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the applicant has claimed priority of a previous application under section 37E;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the missing description or missing drawing is completely contained in the previous application;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: when filing the description or drawing, the applicant makes, in accordance with the rules, a request that the date of filing accorded in accordance with section 37M(2) remains unchanged; and

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.leadIn: the applicant files within the prescribed time—

subparagraph.content: a copy of the previous application;
if the previous application is not in one of the official languages, its translation in one of the official languages; and
a statement indicating the location of the description or drawing in the previous application and, if applicable, in its translation.

subsection.leadIn: In this section—
subsection.def: missing drawing (欠交繪圖) means a drawing referred to in section 37L(2)(b)(iii), that has not been filed in a standard patent (O) application.

section.name: s37O
section.heading: Missing description or missing drawing not filed or withdrawn

subsection.content: If any missing description or missing drawing as defined by section 37N(6) is not filed within the prescribed time under section 37N(1) or (2), any reference to the description or drawing in the specification contained in the standard patent (O) application under section 37L(2)(b) is to be regarded as being deleted.

If a notice of change of the date of filing is issued under section 37N(4), the applicant of the standard patent (O) application may, within 1 month after the date of the notice, withdraw the missing description or missing drawing that has been filed.

subsection.leadIn: On the withdrawal of the description or drawing—

paragraph.name: a
b
paragraph.content: the description or drawing is to be regarded as not having been filed; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the original date of filing of the patent application accorded in accordance with section 37M(2) is to remain unchanged.

division.name: D4
division.heading: Examination on Formal Requirements and Publication of Standard Patent (O) Application

section.name: s37P
section.heading: Examination on formal requirements

subsection.content: If a standard patent (O) application has been accorded a date of filing and is not regarded as being withdrawn under section 37L(6), the Registrar must examine the application to ascertain whether the requirements of section 37L and of any rules made for the purposes of that section (formal requirements) have been complied with.
If there are deficiencies in the application as regards the formal requirements that cannot be corrected, the application must be refused.

If there are deficiencies in the application as regards the formal requirements that may be corrected, the Registrar must give the applicant an opportunity to correct them in accordance with the rules.

subsection.leadIn: If any deficiencies referred to in subsection (3) are not corrected in accordance with the rules, then except as provided in subsection (5)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: where no steps are taken to correct the deficiencies, the application is to be regarded as being withdrawn; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in any other case, the application must be refused.

subsection.content: If a deficiency relating solely to a claim to any right of priority is not duly corrected, then only the right is lost for the application.

section.name: s37Q
section.heading: Publication of application

subsection.leadIn: If a standard patent (O) application has been accorded a date of filing, and the Registrar is satisfied that the application complies with the formal requirements under section 37P, the Registrar must—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: publish the application as filed, together with any subsequent amendment, as soon as practicable on the expiry of the prescribed time, unless the application is withdrawn or refused before preparations for its publication are completed by the Registrar; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: advertise the fact of the publication by notice in the official journal.

subsection.content: The Registrar may publish the application within the prescribed time referred to in subsection (1)(a), if so requested by the applicant.

subsection.leadIn: In publishing the application, the Registrar may omit from the specification contained in the application any matter—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: that, in the Registrar’s opinion, disparages any person in a way likely to damage the person; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: the publication or working of which, in the Registrar’s opinion, would—

subparagraph.content: be contrary to public order (“ordre public”) or morality; or
be likely to encourage offensive, immoral or anti-social behaviour.

subsection.leadIn: In subsection (1)(a)—
subsection.def: subsequent amendment (其後修訂), for a standard patent (O) application, includes any amendment to the claims in, and any new claim added to, the application as filed, before preparations for publication of the application are completed by the Registrar.

section.name: s37R
section.heading: Observations by third parties on patentability of invention

subsection.content: After a standard patent (O) application for an invention has been published, any person may file with the Registrar a written notice of the person’s observations on the patentability of the invention.

subsection.leadIn: The notice must—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: set out the observations and the grounds for the observations; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: be filed in the prescribed manner and within the prescribed time.

subsection.content: The Registrar must, as soon as practicable after receiving a notice under subsection (1), send a copy of the notice to the applicant.
The Registrar must consider the observations when carrying out a substantive examination of the patent application.
A person does not become a party to any proceedings under this Ordinance only because the person files a notice under subsection (1).

division.name: D5
division.heading: Substantive Examination of Standard Patent (O) Applications and Grant of Standard Patents (O)

section.name: s37S
section.heading: Interpretation of Division 5 of Part 3
section.leadIn: In this Division—
section.def: examination requirement (審查規定) means a requirement specified in section 37U(3);

def.name: UnfulfilledRequirement
def.leadIn: unfulfilled requirement (不獲符合的規定), for a standard patent (O) application, means an examination requirement that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in the Registrar’s opinion, is not complied with by the application; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: is set out in the notice to the applicant under section 37V(2).

section.name: s37T
section.heading: Request for substantive examination of standard patent (O) application

subsection.content: The applicant of a standard patent (O) application must, in accordance with the rules, request the Registrar to carry out a substantive examination of the application.

subsection.leadIn: The application is to be regarded as being withdrawn if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: no request for substantive examination is made within the prescribed time; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: where a request has been made, the prescribed fee for the examination is not paid within the prescribed time or the grace period provided in the rules.

section.name: s37U
section.heading: Substantive examination by Registrar

subsection.content: On receiving a request for substantive examination of a standard patent (O) application and the prescribed fee, the Registrar must, by written notice, inform the applicant that the application has entered into the stage of substantive examination.
The Registrar must examine the application to determine whether the application complies with all the requirements specified in subsection (3).

subsection.leadIn: The requirements are—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the invention, which is the subject of the application, is patentable under section 9A;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the specification contained in the application discloses the invention in accordance with section 77;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: all the claims contained in the specification comply with the requirements of section 78(1);

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.leadIn: the matter disclosed in the specification contained in the application does not extend beyond that disclosed in—

subparagraph.content: the application as filed; and
if the application is a specified new application, the earlier standard patent (O) application as filed;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.leadIn: the application is not one of 2 relevant patent applications that—

subparagraph.content: are filed for the same invention made by the same inventor; and
have the same material date.

subsection.leadIn: In examining a standard patent (O) application to determine whether the application complies with the requirement specified in subsection (3)(a), the Registrar must have regard to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: if a claim for priority of a previous application has been made in respect of the application under section 37E, whether the applicant is entitled to the priority claimed; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if a missing description or missing drawing as defined by section 37N(6) has been filed, whether the date of filing of the application remains unchanged.

subsection.content: The Registrar must carry out the examination in accordance with the rules.

subsection.leadIn: In subsection (3)—

def.name: RelevantPatentApplication
def.leadIn: relevant patent application (有關專利申請) means—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a patent application which is pending; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a patent application because of which a patent, being one that is in force, was granted;

def.name: SpecifiedNewApplication
def.leadIn: specified new application (指明新申請) means—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a new standard patent (O) application made in accordance with an order under section 37J(2);

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a new standard patent (O) application referred to in section 37Z; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: a new standard patent (O) application made in accordance with an order under section 55(4).

section.name: s37V
section.heading: Applicant may file representations and requests for amendment, etc.

subsection.content: If the Registrar is of the opinion that a standard patent (O) application does not comply with any examination requirement, the Registrar must, by written notice, inform the applicant of the opinion.
The notice must set out each examination requirement that, in the Registrar’s opinion, is not complied with by the application.

subsection.leadIn: The applicant may respond to the notice by filing, in accordance with the rules, any or all of the following—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a representation to establish that the application complies with an unfulfilled requirement;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: subject to section 103(2), a request to amend the application to enable the application to comply with an unfulfilled requirement;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: a request to review the Registrar’s opinion.

section.name: s37W
section.heading: Registrar must consider representations and requests for amendment, etc.
section.leadIn: The Registrar must, in accordance with the rules—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: consider and decide—

subparagraph.content: whether a representation filed under section 37V(3)(a) establishes that a standard patent (O) application complies with an unfulfilled requirement; and
whether a requested amendment filed under section 37V(3)(b) would enable the application to comply with an unfulfilled requirement; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: review the Registrar’s opinion on a request filed under section 37V(3)(c).

section.name: s37X
section.heading: Grant of standard patent (O)

subsection.leadIn: The Registrar must grant a standard patent (O) for an invention, if the Registrar—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: has examined the standard patent (O) application;

paragraph.name: b
c
paragraph.content: is of the opinion that the application, together with any requested amendment, complies with all the examination requirements.

subsection.leadIn: As soon as practicable after the standard patent (O) is granted, the Registrar must—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: publish in the prescribed manner—

subparagraph.content: the specification of the patent;
the name of the applicant; and
the name of the inventor;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: issue a certificate of grant in respect of the patent to the applicant; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: advertise the fact of the grant by notice in the official journal.

subsection.content: The Registrar may, in addition to the matters specified in subsection (2)(a), publish any other matters constituting or relating to the patent that the Registrar considers it desirable to publish.

section.name: s37Y
section.heading: Refusal to grant standard patent (O)
section.leadIn: The Registrar must refuse to grant a standard patent (O) for an invention, if the Registrar—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: has examined the standard patent (O) application;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: has considered the representation and requested amendment, and reviewed the Registrar’s opinion, under section 37W (where applicable); and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: is of the opinion that the application, together with any requested amendment, does not comply with all the examination requirements.

division.name: D6
division.heading: Provisions on Standard Patent (O) Applications before Grant

section.name: s37Z
section.heading: Divisional standard patent (O) application

subsection.leadIn: Subsection (2) applies if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a standard patent (O) application (earlier application) has been filed; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the applicant or the applicant’s successor in title files a new standard patent (O) application that meets the conditions specified in subsection (3).

subsection.leadIn: Subject to section 103(1)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the date of filing of the earlier application is regarded as the date of filing of the new application; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the new application enjoys the benefit of any right of priority.

subsection.leadIn: The conditions are—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: the new application is filed—

subparagraph.content: before the earlier application is withdrawn;
before the earlier application is regarded as being withdrawn;
if a standard patent (O) has been granted because of the earlier application, before preparations for publication under section 37X(2)(a) of the specification of the patent are completed; or
within the prescribed time after the earlier application is refused by the Registrar; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: the new application—

subparagraph.content: is made in respect of any part of the subject-matter contained in the earlier application; and
complies with the prescribed requirements.

section.name: s37ZA
section.heading: Amendment of standard patent (O) application before grant

subsection.content: subject to section 103(2), the applicant of a standard patent (O) application may amend the application in accordance with the rules within the prescribed time.
The Registrar may, on the Registrar’s initiative, amend the specification and abstract contained in a standard patent (O) application so as to acknowledge a registered trade mark.

section.name: s37ZB
section.heading: Withdrawal of standard patent (O) application

subsection.content: An applicant may, by written notice, withdraw a standard patent (O) application at any time before preparations for publication under section 37X(2)(a) of the specification of the standard patent (O) are completed.
A notice of withdrawal is irrevocable.

section.name: s37ZC
section.heading: Effect of withdrawal and refusal of standard patent (O) application
section.leadIn: If a standard patent (O) application is withdrawn, is regarded as being withdrawn, or is refused, under this Ordinance—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: section 9B(3) continues to apply as regards the application if the application has been published;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the applicant continues to enjoy, on the basis of the application, a right of priority under section 37C or 110 for filing a subsequent standard patent (O) application or short-term patent application; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: no other right may be claimed under this Ordinance in relation to the application.

section.name: s37ZD
section.heading: Further processing of, and restoration of rights in respect of, standard patent (O) application

subsection.leadIn: Sections 28(1) and (2), 29(1), (2) and (3) and 30 apply, subject to the necessary modifications, to an application for a standard patent (O) as if—

paragraph.name: a
b
paragraph.content: a reference in those sections to Part 2 were a reference to this Part; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the words “the request to record had been published under section 20” in section 29(3) were substituted by the words “the application had been published under section 37Q”.

subsection.leadIn: Section 28(1) and (2), as applied by subsection (1), does not apply to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a standard patent (O) application that is regarded as being withdrawn under section 37L(6) or 37T(2)(b); or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a standard patent (O) application that is refused under section 37Y because the applicant fails to comply with a time limit under the rules made for the purposes of section 37V or 37W.

subsection.content: Section 29(1) and (2), as applied by subsection (1), does not apply to a failure to comply with a time limit under section 37D, 37E, 37N, 37O, 37Z, 37ZA or 37ZB.

section.name: s38
section.heading: Deemed date of filing where standard patent (R) has been granted
section.content: Where a standard patent (R) is granted, the application for the standard patent (R) shall be deemed to have as its date of filing the date of filing of the corresponding designated patent application, and in this Ordinance deemed date of filing (當作提交日期) in relation to an application for a standard patent (R) shall be construed accordingly.

section.name: s39
section.heading: Term of standard patent

subsection.leadIn: A standard patent granted under this Ordinance—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: shall take effect from the date on which the fact of its grant is advertised in the official journal; and (Amended 2 of 2001 s. 14)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: subject to subsection (2), shall remain in force until the end of the period of 20 years beginning with— (Amended 17 of 2016 s. 48)

subparagraph.content: for a standard patent (R), the deemed date of filing of the application for the patent;
for a standard patent (O), the date of filing of the application for the patent. (Amended 17 of 2016 s. 48)

subsection.content: If it is desired to keep a standard patent in force for a further year after the expiry of the 3rd or any succeeding year from the date specified in subsection (3), the prescribed renewal fee shall be paid before the expiry of that 3rd or, as the case may be, succeeding year, but not earlier than a date 3 months before that expiry, and a standard patent shall cease to have effect at the expiry of that 3rd or succeeding year if the renewal fee is not so paid.

subsection.leadIn: The date specified for the purpose of subsection (2) is— (Amended 17 of 2016 s. 48)

paragraph.name: a
b
paragraph.content: for a standard patent (O), the anniversary of the date of filing of the application for the patent first occurring after the date of grant of the patent. (Amended 17 of 2016 s. 48)

subsection.leadIn: If within 6 months after the end of the period specified in subsection (2) for payment of the renewal fee the renewal fee and any prescribed additional fee are paid, the standard patent shall be treated as if it had never expired, and accordingly—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: anything done under or in relation to it during that further period shall be valid;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: an act which would constitute an infringement of it if it had not expired shall constitute such an infringement; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: an act which would constitute Government use of the patented invention if the patent had not expired shall constitute that use.

subsection.content: The Registrar may by regulation amend the period specified in subsection (2) by reference to which the earliest date for payment of the prescribed renewal fee is determined.

subsection.leadIn: The Chief Executive in Council may by regulation amend— (Amended 22 of 1999 s. 3)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the period specified in subsection (1)(b) as being the period for which a standard patent shall remain in force;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the period specified in subsection (2) by reference to which a standard patent, if not renewed, shall cease to have effect.

section.name: s40
section.heading: Restoration of lapsed standard patents

subsection.content: Where a standard patent has ceased to have effect by reason of the failure to pay any renewal fee as provided in section 39, application may be made to the Registrar, at any time within 18 months after the date on which the patent ceased to have effect, for the restoration of the patent.

An application under this section may be made by the person who was the proprietor of the standard patent at the time it ceased to have effect or by any other person who would have been entitled to the patent if it had not ceased to have effect; and where the patent was at that time held by 2 or more persons jointly the application may, with the leave of the Registrar, be made by one or more of them without joining the others.
The Registrar shall advertise in the official journal notice of any application under this section. (Amended 2 of 2001 s. 14)

If the Registrar is satisfied that the failure to pay any renewal fee as provided in section 39, or to pay that fee and any additional fee under that section within 6 months after the end of that period, occurred in spite of the applicant having taken all reasonable care required by the circumstances the Registrar shall by order restore the patent on payment of any such unpaid renewal fee and any prescribed additional fee.
An order under this section may be made subject to such terms and conditions as the Registrar thinks fit.

section.name: s41
section.heading: Effect of order for restoration of standard patent

subsection.content: The effect of an order for the restoration of a standard patent is as follows.

subsection.leadIn: Anything done during the period between expiry and restoration which would have constituted an infringement if the patent had not expired shall be treated as an infringement—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: if done at a time when it was possible for the patent to be renewed under section 39(4); or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if it was a continuation or repetition of an earlier infringing act.

subsection.leadIn: A person who in Hong Kong, after it was no longer possible for the patent to be so renewed and before advertisement in the official journal of notice of an application for restoration under section 40— (Amended 2 of 2001 s. 14)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: began in good faith to do an act which would constitute an infringement of the patent if it were in force; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: made in good faith effective and serious preparations to do such an act,

subsection.continued: has the rights specified in subsection (4).

subsection.leadIn: The rights referred to in subsection (3) are—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the right to continue to do or, as the case may be, to do the act referred to in subsection (3);

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: if such act was done or preparations had been made to do it in the course of a business—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.leadIn: in the case of an individual—

subparagraph.name: A
subparagraph.content: the right to assign the right to do it or to transmit such right on death; or

subparagraph.name: B
subparagraph.content: the right to authorize the doing of that act by any of his partners for the time being in the business in the course of which the act was done or preparations had been made to do it;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: in the case of a body corporate, the right to assign the right to do it or to transmit such right on the body’s dissolution,

subsection.continued: and the doing of that act by virtue of this subsection shall not amount to an infringement of the patent concerned.

subsection.content: The rights specified in subsection (4) shall not include the right to grant a licence to any person to do an act referred to in subsection (3).

Where a patented product is disposed of to another in exercise of a right conferred by subsection (4), that other and any person claiming through him may deal with the product in the same way as if it had been disposed of by a registered proprietor of the patent.

section.name: s42
section.heading: Determination after grant of questions referred before grant

subsection.content: If a question with respect to a standard patent or application for a standard patent is referred by any person to the Registrar or the court under section 13 or 37H, whether before or after the making of an application for the patent, and is not determined before the time when the application is first in order for a grant of a patent in pursuance of the application, that fact shall not prevent the grant of a standard patent, but on its grant that person shall be treated as having referred to the Registrar or the court under section 55 any question mentioned in that section which the Registrar or the court thinks appropriate.

In determining any such question under section 55 the Registrar shall exercise only the powers that are available to him for the purposes of determining the same question referred to him under section 13 or 37H.

section.name: s43
section.heading: Amendment of standard patent (R) following opposition or revocation proceedings in the designated patent office

subsection.content: If the specification of the corresponding designated patent in respect of a standard patent (R) granted under Part 2 has (whether before or after the grant of the standard patent (R)) been amended in the designated patent office following prescribed opposition or revocation proceedings, the proprietor of the standard patent (R) shall file with the Registrar in the prescribed manner and within the prescribed period a verified copy of the amended specification or the amending order or other prescribed documentation.

The Registrar shall record the amendment to the specification of the designated patent by making an appropriate entry in the register and upon that recording the standard patent (R) shall be treated as having been amended in a like manner.

subsection.leadIn: As soon as practicable after a standard patent (R) has been amended under this section the Registrar shall— (Amended 17 of 2016 s. 50)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: publish the amendment;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: advertise the fact of the amendment by notice in the official journal. (Amended 2 of 2001 s. 14)

subsection.content: Any amendment of the specification of a standard patent (R) under this section shall have effect from the date of grant of the patent.
Any amendment of the specification of a standard patent (R) under this section shall have effect subject to section 103(3).

section.name: s44
section.heading: Revocation of standard patent (R) following opposition or revocation proceedings in the designated patent office

subsection.content: This section applies to any standard patent (R) of which the corresponding designated patent has been revoked following prescribed opposition or revocation proceedings in the designated patent office.

The proprietor of a standard patent (R) to which this section applies shall after publication of the revocation by the designated patent office and in the prescribed manner file with the Registrar a verified copy of the order of revocation or other prescribed documentation.
The Registrar shall record any filing under subsection (2) and shall advertise the fact of such filing by notice in the official journal. (Amended 2 of 2001 s. 14)

A person other than the proprietor of a standard patent (R) to which this section applies may apply to the Registrar in the prescribed manner for an order under this subsection, and where on such an application the Registrar is satisfied that the patent is one to which this section applies he shall, subject to subsection (5), order that the patent be revoked.
The Registrar may, if he thinks fit, refer any application under subsection (4) to the court and the court shall have jurisdiction to make an order for the revocation of the patent.

Upon the Registrar advertising the fact of a filing by the proprietor of a standard patent (R) under subsection (2) in the official journal, or upon the making of an order by the Registrar under subsection (4) or by the court under subsection (5) for the revocation of a standard patent (R), the patent shall be treated as never having had effect. (Amended 2 of 2001 s. 14)

section.name: s46
section.heading: Application to amend specification after grant

subsection.content: Subject to section 103(3), the proprietor of a patent may apply to amend the specification of the patent.

subsection.leadIn: An application under subsection (1) must be made—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: for a standard patent (R), to the court;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: for a standard patent (O), to the Registrar or the court;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: for a short-term patent in respect of which a certificate of substantive examination has been issued, to the Registrar or the court.

subsection.leadIn: The Registrar or the court (as the case requires) must, in accordance with the rules made by the Registrar or the court—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: publish an application to amend the specification of a patent;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: advertise the fact of the publication by notice in the official journal; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: consider any opposition to the application filed within the prescribed time.

subsection.leadIn: Despite subsection (3), the Registrar may decide not to publish the application or a part of the application if, in the Registrar’s opinion, the amendment proposed in the application or the part—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: would cause the specification of the patent to contravene section 77 or 78;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: contains any matter that disparages any person in a way likely to damage the person;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.leadIn: contains any matter the publication or working of which would—

subparagraph.content: be contrary to public order (“ordre public”) or morality; or
be likely to encourage offensive, immoral or anti-social behaviour; or

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: is invalid under section 103(3).

subsection.leadIn: The Registrar or the court may by order—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: allow an amendment to the specification of a patent; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: attach conditions to the amendment that the Registrar or the court thinks fit.

subsection.content: No amendment may be allowed under subsection (5) if there are pending before the court proceedings in which the validity of the patent may be put in issue.

subsection.leadIn: If an amendment to the specification of a patent is allowed by the Registrar or the court under subsection (5), the Registrar must, in accordance with the rules—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: record and publish the amendment; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: advertise the fact of the publication by notice in the official journal.

subsection.content: The Registrar may, on the Registrar’s initiative, amend the specification of a patent so as to acknowledge a registered trade mark.
An amendment to the specification of a patent under this section has effect as from the grant of the patent.

subsection.leadIn: The rules of court may provide for—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the manner in which an application under this section is to be made to the court;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the notification of the application to the Registrar and the Registrar’s appearance in proceedings;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the filing of opposition to the application; and

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: the procedures for determining the application.

subsection.content: This section, as in force immediately before the commencement date* of the Patents (Amendment) Ordinance 2016 (17 of 2016), continues to apply to an application that is filed with the court before that date to amend the specification of a patent.

section.name: s47
section.heading: Patent not to be impugned for lack of unity
section.leadIn: No person may in any proceedings object to a patent or to an amendment of a specification of a patent on the ground that the claims contained in the specification of the patent, as they stand or, as the case may be, as proposed to be amended, relate—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: to more than one invention; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: to a group of inventions which are not so linked as to form a single inventive concept.

section.name: s48
section.heading: Surrender of patents

subsection.content: The proprietor of a patent may at any time by written notice given to the Registrar offer to surrender his patent.

Any person may give notice to the Registrar of his opposition to the surrender of a patent under this section, and if he does so the Registrar shall notify the proprietor of the patent and, subject to subsection (4), shall determine the question.

If the Registrar is satisfied that the patent may properly be surrendered he may accept the offer and, as from the date on which notice of his acceptance is advertised in the official journal, the patent shall cease to have effect, but no action for infringement shall lie in respect of any act done before that date and no right to compensation shall accrue for any Government use of the patented invention before that date. (Amended 2 of 2001 s. 14)
The Registrar may if he thinks fit refer the matter to the court for determination.

section.name: s49
section.heading: Registrar’s power to revoke patent on grounds of “ordre public” or morality

subsection.content: Any person may at any time after a patent has been granted for an invention under this Ordinance refer to the Registrar the question of whether, having regard to any of the matters specified in section 9A(5), the invention is a patentable invention.

subsection.leadIn: Where a question is so referred—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: subject to paragraph (b), the Registrar shall determine the question;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the Registrar may if he thinks fit refer the question to be determined by the court and, without prejudice to the court’s jurisdiction apart from this paragraph to determine any such question, the court shall have jurisdiction to do so.

subsection.content: If the Registrar or the court determines that the invention is not a patentable invention by reason of any of the matters specified in section 9A(5) he or it shall order that the patent shall be revoked and upon the making of such an order the patent shall be treated as never having had effect.
Any person may oppose a reference under subsection (1).

part.name: P5
part.heading: Property in Patents and Applications; Registration

section.name: s50
section.heading: Nature of, and transactions in, patents and applications for patents

subsection.content: Any patent or application for a patent is personal property (without being a thing in action), and any patent or any such application and rights in or under it may be transferred, created or granted in accordance with subsections (2) to (7).
Subject to section 54, any patent or any such application, or any right in it, may be assigned or mortgaged.
Any patent or any such application or right shall vest by operation of law in the same way as any other personal property and may be vested by an assent of personal representatives.

subsection.leadIn: Subject to section 54, a licence may be granted under any patent or any such application for working the invention which is the subject of the patent or the application; and—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: to the extent that the licence so provides, a sub-licence may be granted under any such licence and any such licence or sub-licence may be assigned or mortgaged; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: any such licence or sub-licence shall vest by operation of law in the same way as any other personal property and may be vested by an assent of personal representatives.

subsection.content: Subsections (2) to (4) shall have effect subject to this Ordinance.

subsection.leadIn: Any of the following transactions, that is to say—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: any assignment or mortgage of a patent or any such application, or any right in a patent or any such application;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: any assent relating to any patent or any such application or right,

subsection.continued: shall be void unless it is in writing and is signed by or on behalf of the assignor, mortgagor or party granting such assent as the case may be (or, in the case of an assent or other transaction by a personal representative, by or on behalf of the personal representative) or in the case of a body corporate is so signed or is under the seal of that body.

subsection.content: An assignment of a patent or any such application or a share in it, and an exclusive licence granted under any patent or any such application, may confer on the assignee or licensee the right of the assignor or licensor to bring proceedings by virtue of section 80 or 88 for a previous infringement or to bring proceedings under section 72 for a previous act.

section.name: s51
section.heading: Register of patents

subsection.content: The Registrar shall keep a register to be known as the register of patents, which shall comply with rules made for the purposes of this section and shall be kept in accordance with such rules.

subsection.leadIn: Without prejudice to any other provision of this Ordinance—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: rules shall be made providing for the registration of—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: patents and of published applications for standard patents; and

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: transactions, instruments or events affecting rights in or under patents and published applications for standard patents;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: rules made for the purposes of this section may provide, in connection with rules made for the purposes of paragraph (a), for—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: the furnishing to the Registrar of any prescribed documents or description of documents in connection with any matter which is required to be registered;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: the correction of errors in the register and in any documents filed with the Registrar in connection with registration; and

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: the publication and advertisement of anything done under this Ordinance in relation to the register; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: rules made for the purposes of this section may provide for notification to the Registrar of any matter affecting the property in an application for a patent.

subsection.content: Notwithstanding subsection (2)(a)(ii), no notice of any trust, whether express, implied or constructive, shall be entered in the register and the Registrar shall not be affected by any such notice.
The register need not be kept in documentary form.
Subject to any rules, the public shall have a right to inspect the register at the registry at all convenient times.

Any person who applies for a certified copy of an entry in the register or a certified extract from the register shall be entitled to obtain such a copy or extract on payment of a fee prescribed in relation to certified copies and extracts; and rules may provide that any person who applies for an uncertified copy or extract shall be entitled to such a copy or extract on payment of a fee prescribed in relation to uncertified copies and extracts.
Applications under subsection (6) or rules made by virtue of that subsection shall be made in such manner as may be prescribed.

subsection.leadIn: In relation to any portion of the register kept otherwise than in documentary form—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the right of inspection conferred by subsection (5) is a right to inspect the material on the register; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the right to a copy or extract conferred by subsection (6) or rules is a right to a copy or extract in a form in which it can be taken away and in which it is visible and legible.

subsection.content: Subject to subsection (12), the register shall be prima facie evidence of anything required or authorized by this Ordinance to be registered.

A certificate purporting to be signed by the Registrar and certifying that any entry which he is authorized by this Ordinance to make has or has not been made, or that any other thing which he is so authorized to do has or has not been done, shall be prima facie evidence of the matters so certified.

subsection.leadIn: Each of the following, that is to say—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a copy of an entry in the register or an extract from the register which is supplied under subsection (6);

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a copy of any document kept at the registry or an extract from any such document, any specification of a patent or any application for a standard patent which has been published,

subsection.continued: which purports to be a certified copy or a certified extract shall, subject to subsection (12), be admitted in evidence without further proof and without production of any original.

subsection.content: This section is without prejudice to section 22A or 22B or Part IV of the Evidence Ordinance (Cap. 8) or any provision made by virtue of that section or Part. (Replaced 2 of 1999 s. 6)

subsection.def: In this section certified copy (核證副本) and certified extract (核證摘錄) mean a copy and extract certified by the Registrar and sealed with the seal of the Registrar.

section.name: s52
section.heading: Effect of registration procedures on rights in patents

subsection.leadIn: Any person who claims to have acquired the property in a patent or application for a patent by virtue of any transaction, instrument or event to which this section applies shall be entitled as against any other person who claims to have acquired that property by virtue of an earlier transaction, instrument or event to which this section applies if, at the time of the later transaction, instrument or event—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: either—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: application has not been made for registration of the earlier transaction, instrument or event; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: in the case of any application for a standard patent which has not been published or any application for a short-term patent, notice of the earlier transaction, instrument or event has not been given to the Registrar in accordance with rules (if any) made for the purposes of section 51(2)(c); and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the person claiming under the later transaction, instrument or event did not know of the earlier transaction, instrument or event.

subsection.content: Subsection (1) shall apply equally to the case where any person claims to have acquired any right in or under a patent or application for a patent by virtue of a transaction, instrument or event to which this section applies, and that right is incompatible with any such right acquired by virtue of an earlier transaction, instrument or event to which this section applies.

subsection.leadIn: This section applies to the following transactions, instruments and events—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the assignment of a patent or application for a patent, or a right in it;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the mortgage of a patent or application or the granting of security over it;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the grant or assignment of a licence or sub-licence or mortgage of a licence or sub-licence under a patent or application;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: the death of the proprietor or one of the proprietors of any such patent or application or any person having a right in or under a patent or application and the vesting by an assent of personal representatives of a patent, application or any such right; and

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: any order or directions of a court or other competent authority transferring a patent or application or any right in or under it to any person and the event by virtue of which the court or authority had power to make any such order or give any such directions.

section.name: s53
section.heading: Rectification of register

subsection.content: The court may, on the application of any person aggrieved, order the register to be rectified by the making, or the variation or deletion, of any entry in it.
In proceedings under this section the court may determine any question which it may be necessary or expedient to decide in connection with the rectification of the register.

section.name: s54
section.heading: Co-ownership of patents and applications for patents

subsection.content: Where a patent is granted to 2 or more persons each of them shall, subject to any agreement to the contrary, be entitled to an equal undivided share in the patent.

Where 2 or more persons are proprietors of a patent, then, subject to this section and to any agreement to the contrary, each of them shall be entitled, by himself or his agent, to do in respect of the invention concerned, for his own benefit and without the consent of or the need to account to the other or others, any act which would apart from this subsection and sections 68 and 69 amount to an infringement of the patent concerned; and any such act shall not amount to an infringement of the patent concerned.

subsection.leadIn: Subject to sections 13, 37H, 37I, 37J and 55 and to any agreement for the time being in force, where 2 or more persons are proprietors of a patent one of them shall not without the consent of the other or others— (Amended 17 of 2016 s. 57)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: make an application for amending the specification of the patent or for revoking the patent; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: grant a licence under the patent, or assign or mortgage a share in the patent. (Amended 17 of 2016 s. 57)

subsection.content: Subject to those sections, where 2 or more persons are proprietors of a patent, anyone else may supply one of those persons with the means, relating to an essential element of the invention, for putting the invention into effect, and the supply of those means by virtue of this subsection shall not amount to an infringement of the patent.

Where a patented product is disposed of by any of 2 or more proprietors to any person, that person and any other person claiming through him shall be entitled to deal with the product in the same way as if it had been disposed of by a sole registered proprietor.
Nothing in subsection (1) or (2) shall affect the mutual rights or obligations of trustees or of the personal representatives of a deceased person, or their rights or obligations as such.

subsection.leadIn: This section shall have effect in relation to an application for a patent as filed as it has effect in relation to a patent and—

paragraph.name: a
