paragraph.content: attach to the notice all the documents and documentary evidence required under subsection (2)(b) (except subparagraphs (iii) and (iv) of that subsection); and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: as soon as practicable after notice is given under paragraph (a), submit a copy of the notice to the Director.

section.name: s72M
section.heading: Grant of export compulsory licences for patented pharmaceutical products
section.leadIn: The Director may grant an export compulsory licence under the patent concerned, subject to such terms and conditions as he may impose, to an applicant to make a patented pharmaceutical product and sell the product for export to an eligible importing member if he is satisfied that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: all the requirements of section 72L have been met;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the amount of the product applied for by the applicant to be made and sold for export under the licence does not exceed the amount stated in the notification referred to in section 72L(2)(b)(ii)(A), after taking into account any information obtained pursuant to section 72L(3); and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the application is made in response to the request from the eligible importing member referred to in section 72L(2)(b)(i).

section.name: s72N
section.heading: Terms, conditions and nature of export compulsory licences

subsection.leadIn: The terms and conditions subject to which an export compulsory licence is granted under section 72M shall include—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: terms and conditions in respect of—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: the acts authorized to be done in relation to the patented pharmaceutical product under the licence;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: the amount of the patented pharmaceutical product authorized to be made and sold for export under the licence;

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: the eligible importing member to which the patented pharmaceutical product is to be exported under the licence; and

subparagraph.name: iv
subparagraph.content: the duration of the licence;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: terms and conditions providing that—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: the licence is non-assignable except with that part of the enterprise or goodwill which enjoys the use of the patent under the licence;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.leadIn: the patented pharmaceutical product shall be—

subparagraph.name: A
subparagraph.content: clearly identified as being made under the licence through specific labelling or marking; and

subparagraph.name: B
iii
subparagraph.leadIn: the export compulsory licensee shall, before shipment of the patented pharmaceutical product to the eligible importing member under the licence, post on the website maintained by or on behalf of the licensee or on the WTO website information in relation to—

subparagraph.name: A
B
subparagraph.content: the labelling, marking, packaging, colouring or shaping for the patented pharmaceutical product required by subparagraph (ii);

subparagraph.name: iv
subparagraph.content: the export compulsory licensee shall pay to the proprietor of the patent concerned such amount of remuneration as determined by the Director under section 72P(1) for the export compulsory licence in relation to the product;

subparagraph.name: v
subparagraph.content: where there is more than one patent in relation to the patented pharmaceutical product, the export compulsory licensee shall apportion on an equal share basis among all the proprietors of the patents concerned the total amount of remuneration determined by the Director under section 72P(1);

subparagraph.name: vi
subparagraph.content: subject to subparagraph (vii), the patented pharmaceutical product made under the licence shall be exported only to the eligible importing member specified in the licence; and

subparagraph.name: vii
subparagraph.content: if the patented pharmaceutical product is also patented in the eligible importing member, the product shall be exported to the eligible importing member after it has granted a compulsory licence for importation of the product; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: any other terms or conditions as the Director thinks fit.

subsection.content: An export compulsory licence is non-exclusive.

section.name: s72O
section.heading: Notification of grant of export compulsory licences
section.leadIn: The Director shall as soon as practicable after the grant of an export compulsory licence under section 72M—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: give notice in writing to the proprietor of the patent concerned, as identified pursuant to the information specified in the application in accordance with section 72L(2)(a)(vi), of the grant of the licence and its terms and conditions; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: advertise in the official journal notice of the grant of the licence and its terms and conditions.

section.name: s72P
section.heading: Determination of remuneration payable to proprietors of patents

subsection.content: The Director shall determine the amount of remuneration payable to the proprietor of the patent concerned under section 72N(1)(b)(iv).
In determining the amount of remuneration, the Director shall take into account any advice given by the Director of Intellectual Property as regards the remuneration.

The total amount of remuneration determined by the Director under subsection (1) to be payable in respect of the patent or all the patents (if there is more than one patent in relation to the patented pharmaceutical product) shall not exceed 4% of the total purchase price for the product payable by the eligible importing member to the export compulsory licensee.
The Secretary for Commerce and Economic Development may by notice published in the Gazette vary the percentage specified in subsection (3).

section.name: s72Q
section.heading: Termination of export compulsory licences

subsection.leadIn: The Director may terminate an export compulsory licence by giving notice in writing to the export compulsory licensee if he is satisfied that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: any term or condition of the licence imposed under section 72M has been contravened; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: any information, document or documentary evidence specified in or accompanying the application in accordance with section 72L(2) is false, incorrect or incomplete in any material particular.

subsection.leadIn: The Director shall as soon as practicable after the termination of an export compulsory licence under subsection (1)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: give notice in writing to the proprietor of the patent concerned, as identified pursuant to the information specified in the application in accordance with section 72L(2)(a)(vi), of the termination; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: advertise in the official journal notice of the termination.

section.name: s72R
section.heading: References of disputes as to export compulsory licences

subsection.leadIn: Any person aggrieved by—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the grant of an export compulsory licence;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: any term or condition of an export compulsory licence imposed under section 72M; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the termination of an export compulsory licence under section 72Q(1),

subsection.continued: may, within 28 days after the date of the advertisement of the notice under section 72O(b) or the date of the termination of the licence (as the case may be) or such further period as may be allowed by the court, apply to the court for a review of the grant of the licence, the terms or conditions of the licence or the termination of the licence (as the case may be).

subsection.leadIn: In a review the court may—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: confirm, vary or cancel the export compulsory licence;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: confirm, vary or cancel a term or condition of the export compulsory licence imposed under section 72M;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: confirm or vary the determination of the amount of remuneration under section 72P(1);

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: confirm or reverse the termination of the export compulsory licence under section 72Q(1); or

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: make any other order as the court thinks fit in the circumstances.

subsection.leadIn: In determining the appropriate amount of remuneration payable to the proprietor of the patent concerned, the court shall take into account all factors relevant to the circumstances, including—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the economic value to the eligible importing member of the use of the patented pharmaceutical product exported to it under the relevant export compulsory licence; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: humanitarian or non-commercial factors relevant to the grant of the licence.

subsection.content: The total amount of remuneration determined by the court under subsection (3) to be payable in respect of the patent or all the patents (if there is more than one patent in relation to the patented pharmaceutical product) may exceed the maximum amount of remuneration that may be determined by the Director under section 72P(1).

subsection.leadIn: The proprietor of the patent concerned may apply to the court for an order to terminate an export compulsory licence on the ground that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: any term or condition of the licence imposed under section 72M has been contravened; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: any information, document or documentary evidence specified in or accompanying the application in accordance with section 72L(2) is false, incorrect or incomplete in any material particular.

subsection.leadIn: The court may, on an application under subsection (5)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: make an order to terminate the export compulsory licence if the court is satisfied that—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: any term or condition of the licence imposed under section 72M has been contravened; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: any information, document or documentary evidence specified in or accompanying the application in accordance with section 72L(2) is false, incorrect or incomplete in any material particular; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: make any other order as the court thinks fit in the circumstances.

section.name: s72S
section.heading: Signature of documents by partnerships, companies and associations
section.leadIn: For the purposes of this Part—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a document signed for or on behalf of a firm shall be signed by all of its partners, by any partner stating that he signs on behalf of the firm or by any other person who satisfies the Director that he is authorized by the firm to sign the document;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a document signed for or on behalf of a body corporate shall be signed by a director or the secretary or other principal officer of the body corporate or by any other person who satisfies the Director that he is authorized by the body corporate to sign the document; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: a document signed for or on behalf of an unincorporated body or association of persons other than a firm shall be signed by any person who satisfies the Director that he is authorized by the unincorporated body or association of persons (as the case may be) to sign the document.

part.name: P10
part.heading: Effects of Patent and Patent Application

section.name: s73
section.heading: Prevention of direct use of invention
section.leadIn: A patent while it is in force shall confer on its proprietor the right to prevent all third parties not having his consent from doing in Hong Kong all or any of the following—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: in relation to any product which is the subject-matter of the patent—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: making, putting on the market, using or importing the product; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: stocking the product, whether for the purpose of putting it on the market (in Hong Kong or elsewhere) or otherwise;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: in relation to any process which is the subject-matter of the patent—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: using the process; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: offering the process for use in Hong Kong when the third party knows, or it is obvious to a reasonable person in the circumstances, that the use of the process is prohibited without the consent of the proprietor of the patent;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.leadIn: where the invention is a process, then in relation to any product obtained directly by means of that process—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: putting on the market, using or importing the product; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: stocking the product, whether for the purpose of putting it on the market (in Hong Kong or elsewhere) or otherwise.

section.name: s74
section.heading: Prevention of indirect use of invention

subsection.content: A patent while it is in force shall also confer on its proprietor the right to prevent all third parties not having his consent from supplying or offering to supply in Hong Kong a person, other than a party entitled to work the patented invention, with means, relating to an essential element of that invention, for putting it into effect, when the third party knows, or it is obvious in the circumstances to a reasonable person, that the said means are suitable and intended for putting that invention into effect in Hong Kong.

Subsection (1) shall not apply when the means referred to therein are staple commercial products, unless the supply or offering is made for the purpose of inducing the person supplied or, as the case may be, to whom the offer is made to commit acts which the proprietor of a patent is enabled to prevent by virtue of section 73.
Persons performing acts referred to in section 75(a), (b) or (c) shall not be considered to be parties entitled to work an invention pursuant to subsection (1).

subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of subsection (1)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: reference in that subsection to a person entitled to work an invention includes a reference to a person so entitled by virtue of section 69; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a person who by virtue of section 30, 35, 39(4), 41(4) or (5), 83, 106(4) or 126(5) (including, in the case of section 41, that section as applied by section 127) is entitled to do an act in relation to the invention without it constituting an infringement of a patent for the invention shall, so far as concerns that act, be treated as a person entitled to work the invention.

section.name: s75
section.heading: Limitation of effect of patent
section.leadIn: The rights conferred by a patent shall not extend to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: acts done privately for non-commercial purposes;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: acts done for experimental purposes relating to the subject-matter of the relevant patented invention;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the extemporaneous preparation for individual cases in a pharmacy of a medicine in accordance with a medical prescription issued by a registered medical practitioner or registered dentist (which terms bear the meaning assigned to them by section 2 of the Medical Registration Ordinance (Cap. 161) and section 2(1) of the Dentists Registration Ordinance (Cap. 156) respectively) or acts concerning the medicine so prepared;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.leadIn: the use of the invention which is the subject of the patent—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: on board vessels registered in any of the Paris Convention countries or WTO member countries, territories or areas, other than Hong Kong; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: in the body of such vessels, or in the machinery, tackle, gear or other accessories of such vessels,

paragraph.continued: when such vessels temporarily or accidentally enter the waters of Hong Kong, but only if the invention is used in such waters exclusively for the needs of the vessel; (Amended 21 of 2024 s. 78)

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.leadIn: the use of the invention which is the subject of the patent in the construction or operation of—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: aircraft, hovercraft or land vehicles of Paris Convention countries or WTO member countries, territories or areas, other than Hong Kong; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: such aircraft, hovercraft or land vehicle accessories,

paragraph.continued: when such aircraft, hovercraft or land vehicles temporarily or accidentally enter Hong Kong;

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: the use of an aircraft to which section 10(4) of the Civil Aviation Ordinance (Cap. 448) applies which has lawfully entered or is lawfully crossing Hong Kong (including the air space above it and its waters), or the importation into Hong Kong, or the use or storage there, of any part or accessory for such an aircraft. (Amended 21 of 2024 s. 78)

section.name: s76
section.heading: Extent of invention

subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of this Ordinance—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: an invention in respect of which an application for a patent has been filed shall, unless the context otherwise requires, be taken to be that specified in a claim of the specification of the application, as interpreted by the description and any drawings contained in that specification;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: an invention for which a patent has been granted shall, unless the context otherwise requires, be taken to be that specified in a claim of the specification of the patent, as interpreted by the description and any drawings contained in that specification,

subsection.continued: and the extent of the protection conferred by a patent or an application for a patent shall be determined accordingly.

subsection.content: Where more than one invention is specified in any such claim in relation to a patent or an application for a patent, each invention may have a different date of priority for the purposes of this Ordinance.

subsection.leadIn: Subsection (1) should not be interpreted in either of the following senses, namely—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in the sense that the extent of the protection conferred by a patent is to be understood as that defined by the strict, literal meaning of the wording used in the claims, the description and drawings being employed only for the purpose of resolving an ambiguity found in the claims, on the one hand; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in the sense that the claims serve only as a guideline and that the actual protection conferred by a patent may extend to what, from a consideration of the description and drawings by a person skilled in the art, the patentee has contemplated, on the other hand,

subsection.continued: but rather is to be interpreted as defining a position between these extremes which combines a fair protection for the proprietor of the patent or the application for a patent with a reasonable degree of certainty for third parties.

section.name: s77
section.heading: Disclosure of invention
section.content: The application for and specification of a patent for an invention shall disclose the invention to which it relates in a manner sufficiently clear and complete for it to be performed by a person skilled in the art.

section.name: s78
section.heading: Claims

subsection.leadIn: The claims contained in the specification of a patent application or of a patent must—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: define the matter for which protection is sought or given;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: be clear and concise;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: be supported by the description in the specification; and

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: relate to 1 invention or to a group of inventions that are so linked as to form a single inventive concept.

subsection.content: The rules may provide for the circumstances under which a group of inventions are to be regarded as being so linked as to form a single inventive concept.

This section, as in force immediately before the commencement date* of the Patents (Amendment) Ordinance 2016 (17 of 2016), continues to apply to a patent application filed, or a patent the application for which is filed, before that date.

section.name: s79
section.heading: The abstract
section.content: The abstract shall only serve for use as technical information; it may not be taken into account for any other purpose and in particular it may be used neither for the purpose of interpreting the scope of the protection given nor for the purpose of applying section 9B(3).

section.name: s80
section.heading: Proceedings for infringement of patent

subsection.leadIn: Subject to this Part and section 129(1), civil proceedings may be brought in the court by the proprietor of a patent in respect of any act of infringement which he alleges he is entitled under sections 73 to 75 to prevent and (without prejudice to any other jurisdiction of the court) in those proceedings a claim may be made— (Amended 17 of 2016 s. 73)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: for an injunction restraining the defendant from any apprehended act of such infringement;

paragraph.name: b
c
paragraph.content: for damages in respect of the infringement;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: for an account of the profits derived by the defendant from the infringement;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: for a declaration that the patent is valid and has been infringed by the defendant.

subsection.content: The court shall not, in respect of the same infringement, both award the proprietor of a patent damages and order that he shall be given an account of the profits.

Subject to this Part, in determining whether or not to grant any kind of relief claimed under this section and the extent of the relief granted the court shall apply the principles applied by the court in relation to that kind of relief immediately before the commencement* of this Part.

section.name: s81
section.heading: Restrictions on recovery of damages for infringement

subsection.content: In proceedings for the infringement of a patent damages shall not be awarded, and no order shall be made for an account of profits, against a defendant who proves that at the date of the infringement he was not aware, and had no reasonable grounds for supposing, that the patent existed.

For the purposes of subsection (1) a person shall not be taken to have been so aware or to have had reasonable grounds for so supposing by reason only of the application to a product of the word “patent” or “patented” or “專利” or “取得專利”, or any word or words expressing or implying that a patent has been obtained for the product, unless the number of the patent accompanied the word or words in question.

In proceedings for infringement of a patent the court may, if it thinks fit, refuse to award any damages or make any such order in respect of an infringement committed during the further period specified in section 39(4) or 126(5), as the case may be, but before the payment of the renewal fee and any additional fee prescribed for the purposes of that subsection. (Amended 17 of 2016 s. 74)

Where an amendment of the specification of a patent has been allowed under this Ordinance, no damages shall be awarded in any proceedings for an infringement of the patent committed before the date of the decision to allow the amendment or of the recording of the amendment pursuant to section 43(2), as the case may be, unless the court is satisfied that the specification of the patent as originally published was framed in good faith and with reasonable skill and knowledge.

Without limiting the effect of subsection (4), where an order has been made by the court under section 46(5) allowing an amendment of the specification of a patent, no damages shall be awarded in any proceedings for an infringement of the patent committed after the date on which the order is made and before a copy of the order is filed with the Registrar for the purposes of section 46(7). (Amended 17 of 2016 s. 74)

section.name: s82
section.heading: Relief for infringement of partially valid patent

subsection.content: If the validity of a patent is put in issue in proceedings for infringement of the patent and it is found that the patent is only partially valid, the court may, subject to subsection (2), grant relief in respect of that part of the patent which is found to be valid and infringed.

Where in any such proceedings it is found that a patent is only partially valid, the court shall not grant relief by way of damages or costs, except where the plaintiff proves that the specification for the patent was framed in good faith and with reasonable skill and knowledge, and in that event the court may grant relief in respect of that part of the patent which is valid and infringed, subject to the discretion of the court as to costs and as to the date from which damages should be reckoned.

As a condition of relief under subsection (1) or (2) the court may direct that the specification of the patent shall be amended to its satisfaction upon an application made for that purpose under section 102, and such an application may be made whether or not all other issues in the proceedings have been determined.

section.name: s83
section.heading: Right to continue use begun before priority date

subsection.leadIn: A person has the rights specified in subsection (2) if the person, in Hong Kong and before the material date of a patent—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: does in good faith an act that would constitute an infringement of the patent if the patent were in force; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: makes in good faith effective and serious preparations to do such an act. (Replaced 17 of 2016 s. 75)

subsection.leadIn: The rights referred to in subsection (1) are—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the right to continue to do or, as the case may be, to do the act referred to in subsection (1);

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: if such act was done or preparations had been made to do it in the course of a business—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.leadIn: in the case of an individual—

subparagraph.name: A
subparagraph.content: the right to assign the right to do it or to transmit such right on death; or

subparagraph.name: B
ii
subparagraph.content: in the case of a body corporate, the right to assign the right to do it or to transmit such right on the body’s dissolution,

subsection.continued: and the doing of that act by virtue of this subsection shall not amount to an infringement of the patent concerned.

subsection.content: The rights specified in subsection (2) shall not include the right to grant a licence to any person to do an act referred to in subsection (1).

Where a patented product is disposed of to another in exercise of a right conferred by subsection (2), that other and any person claiming through him may deal with the product in the same way as if it had been disposed of by a registered proprietor of the patent.

section.name: s84
section.heading: Certificate of contested validity of patent

subsection.content: If in any proceedings before the court the validity of a patent to any extent is contested and that patent is found by the court to be wholly or partially valid, the court may certify the finding and the fact that the validity of the patent was so contested.

Where a certificate is granted under this section, then if, in any subsequent proceedings before the court for infringement of the patent concerned or for revocation of the patent, a final order or judgment is made or given in favour of the party relying on the validity of the patent that party shall, unless the court otherwise directs, be entitled to his costs on the indemnity basis within the meaning of that term as appearing in Order 62 rule 28 of the Rules of the High Court (Cap. 4 sub. leg. A) (other than the costs of any appeal in the subsequent proceedings). (Amended 25 of 1998 s. 2; E.R. 4 of 2020)

section.name: s85
section.heading: Proceedings for infringement by a co-owner

subsection.leadIn: In the application of section 73 to a patent of which there are 2 or more joint proprietors the reference to the proprietor shall be construed—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in relation to any act, as a reference to that proprietor or those proprietors who, by virtue of section 54 or any agreement referred to in that section, is or are entitled to do that act without its amounting to an infringement; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in relation to any consent, as a reference to that proprietor or those proprietors who, by virtue of section 54 or any such agreement, is or are the proper person or persons to give the requisite consent.

subsection.content: One of 2 or more joint proprietors of a patent may without the concurrence of the others bring proceedings in respect of an act alleged to infringe the patent, but shall not do so unless the others are made parties to the proceedings, but any of the others made a defendant in pursuance of this subsection shall not be liable for any costs or expenses unless he enters an appearance and takes part in the proceedings.

section.name: s86
section.heading: Proceedings for infringement by exclusive licensee

subsection.content: Subject to this section, the holder of an exclusive licence under a patent shall have the same right as the proprietor of the patent to bring proceedings in respect of any infringement of the patent committed after the date of the licence; and references to the proprietor of the patent in the provisions of this Ordinance relating to infringement shall be construed accordingly.

In awarding damages or granting any other relief in any such proceedings the court shall take into consideration any loss suffered or likely to be suffered by the exclusive licensee as such as a result of the infringement, or, as the case may be, the profits derived from the infringement, so far as it constitutes an infringement of the rights of the exclusive licensee as such.

In any proceedings taken by an exclusive licensee by virtue of this section the proprietor of the patent shall be made a party to the proceedings, but if made a defendant in pursuance of this subsection shall not be liable for costs or expenses unless he enters an appearance and takes part in the proceedings.

section.name: s87
section.heading: Effect of non-registration on infringement proceedings
section.leadIn: Where a person becomes the proprietor or one of the proprietors or an exclusive licensee of a patent by virtue of a transaction, instrument or event to which section 52 applies, then unless—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: an application for registration of the prescribed particulars of the transaction, instrument or event is made before the end of the period of 6 months beginning with its date; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the court is satisfied that it was not practicable for such an application to be made before the end of that period and that an application was made as soon as practicable thereafter,

section.continued: he is not entitled to damages or an account of profits in respect of any infringement of the patent occurring after the date of the transaction, instrument or event and before the prescribed particulars of the transaction, instrument or event are registered.

section.name: s88
section.heading: Infringement of rights conferred by publication of application for standard patent

subsection.content: Subject to this section, where an application for a standard patent is published the applicant shall have, as from the date of publication and until the grant of the standard patent, the same right as he would have had, if the patent had been granted on the date of the publication of the application, to bring proceedings in the court for damages in respect of any act which would have infringed the patent.

subsection.leadIn: Further to subsection (1), references in sections 73, 74, 75, 80, 81 and 85 to 87—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: to a patent and the proprietor of a patent, as they relate to a standard patent, shall be respectively construed as including references to the application for the standard patent and the applicant; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: to a patent being in force, being granted, being valid or existing, as they relate to a standard patent, shall be construed accordingly, and for this purpose, for a standard patent (R), the reference in section 81(3) to section 39(4) shall be read as a reference to section 33(4). (Amended 17 of 2016 s. 76)

subsection.leadIn: The applicant shall be entitled to bring proceedings by virtue of this section in respect of any act only—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: after the standard patent has been granted; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if the act would, if the patent had been granted on the publication date of the request to record (for a standard patent (R)) or the publication date of the patent application (for a standard patent (O)), have infringed not only the standard patent, but also the claims (as interpreted by the description and any drawings referred to in the description or claims) in the form in which they were contained in the published request to record or published application. (Amended 17 of 2016 s. 76)

subsection.content: Section 81(4) shall not apply to an infringement of the rights conferred by this section, but in considering the amount of any damages for such an infringement, the court shall consider whether or not it would have been reasonable to expect, from a consideration of the application for a standard patent as published that a patent would be granted conferring on the proprietor of the patent protection from an act of the same description as that found to infringe those rights, and if the court finds that it would not have been reasonable, it shall reduce the damages to such an amount as it thinks just.
An applicant shall be deemed never to have had the rights set out in subsection (1) if the application for a standard patent is refused or withdrawn or is deemed to be withdrawn.

section.name: s89
section.heading: Remedy for groundless threats of infringement proceedings

subsection.content: Where a person (whether or not the proprietor of, or entitled to any right in, a patent) by circulars, advertisements or otherwise threatens another person with proceedings for infringement of a patent, a person aggrieved by the threats (whether or not he is the person to whom the threats are made) may, subject to subsection (4), bring proceedings in the court against the person making the threats for any such relief as is mentioned in subsection (3).

Subject to section 89A, in any such proceedings the plaintiff shall, if he proves that the threats were so made and satisfies the court that he is a person aggrieved by them, be entitled to the relief claimed. (Amended 17 of 2016 s. 77)

subsection.leadIn: The said relief is—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a declaration to the effect that the threats are unjustifiable;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: an injunction against the continuance of the threats; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: such damages, if any, as have been sustained by the plaintiff by reason of the threats.

subsection.content: Proceedings may not be brought under this section as regards a threat to bring proceedings for an infringement alleged to consist of making a product for putting on the market or of using a process.
For the purposes of this section a notification of the existence of a patent does not of itself constitute a threat of proceedings.

This section, as in force immediately before the commencement date* of the Patents (Amendment) Ordinance 2016 (17 of 2016), continues to apply to proceedings brought under subsection (1) in respect of a threat that is made before that date. (Added 17 of 2016 s. 77)

section.name: s89A
section.heading: Circumstances under which plaintiff not entitled to relief claimed

subsection.leadIn: Where a threat alleged an infringement of a standard patent, the plaintiff in the relief proceedings is not entitled to the relief claimed if—

paragraph.name: a
b
paragraph.content: the plaintiff fails to prove that the patent is invalid in the relevant respect.

subsection.leadIn: Where a threat alleged an infringement of a short-term patent in respect of which a certificate of substantive examination has not been issued, the plaintiff in the relief proceedings is not entitled to the relief claimed if the defendant proves that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the act in respect of which the threat was made constitutes or, if done, would constitute an infringement of the patent;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the patent is valid in the relevant respect; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the defendant has complied with any access request for patent information made by the plaintiff before commencing the relief proceedings.

subsection.leadIn: For subsection (2)(c)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a request is taken to be an access request only if it is made in writing and is accompanied by a copy of this section;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the defendant is taken to have complied with an access request only if the defendant provides the patent information as at the request date to the plaintiff, without charge, within 14 days from the request date or any longer period agreed to by the plaintiff; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the defendant is taken to have complied with an access request in relation to any patent information that the defendant has already provided to the plaintiff on or before the request date.

subsection.leadIn: Where a threat alleged an infringement of a short-term patent in respect of which a certificate of substantive examination has been issued, the plaintiff in the relief proceedings is not entitled to the relief claimed if—

paragraph.name: a
b
paragraph.content: the plaintiff fails to prove that the patent is invalid in the relevant respect.

subsection.content: This section only applies to relief proceedings brought in respect of a threat that is made on or after the commencement date* of the Patents (Amendment) Ordinance 2016 (17 of 2016).

subsection.leadIn: In this section—

def.name: PatentInformation
def.leadIn: patent information (專利資料), for a short-term patent, means—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the number assigned by the Registrar to the certificate of grant issued in respect of the patent under section 118(2)(b); and

paragraph.name: b

subsection.def: relief proceedings (濟助法律程序) means any proceedings brought by a person under section 89(1) in respect of a threat;
request date (請求日期) means the date of delivery of a request;
threat (威脅) means a threat referred to in section 89(1) to bring proceedings for an infringement of a patent.

section.name: s90
section.heading: Declaration as to non-infringement
section.leadIn: Without prejudice to the court’s jurisdiction to make a declaration apart from this section, a declaration that an act does not, or a proposed act would not, constitute an infringement of a patent may be made by the court in proceedings between the person doing or proposing to do the act and the proprietor of the patent, notwithstanding that no assertion to the contrary has been made by the proprietor, if it is shown that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: that person has applied in writing to the proprietor for a written acknowledgment to the effect of the declaration claimed, and has furnished him with full particulars in writing of the act in question; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the proprietor has refused or failed to give any such acknowledgment.

section.name: s91
section.heading: Power to revoke patents on application

subsection.leadIn: Subject to this Ordinance, the court may on the application of any person by order revoke a patent for an invention on (but only on) any of the following grounds, that is to say—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: that the invention is not a patentable invention;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: that the patent was granted to a person who was not entitled to be granted that patent;

paragraph.name: c
d
paragraph.content: that the matter disclosed in the specification of the patent extends beyond that disclosed in the application for the patent as filed or, if the patent was granted on a new application filed under section 55(4) or as mentioned in section 22, 37Z or 116, in the earlier application for a patent as filed;

paragraph.name: e
f
paragraph.leadIn: that the patent is one of 2 patents that—

subparagraph.content: are granted for the same invention made by the same inventor; and
have the same material date; (Replaced 17 of 2016 s. 81)

paragraph.name: i
paragraph.content: in the case of a standard patent (R), that the corresponding designated patent has been revoked following prescribed opposition or revocation proceedings in the designated patent office.

subsection.leadIn: An order under this section may be—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: an order for the unconditional revocation of the patent; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: where the court determines that one of the grounds mentioned in subsection (1)(a), (b), (c), (d), (e) and (f) has been established, but only so as to invalidate the patent to a limited extent, an order that the patent should be revoked unless within a specified time the specification is amended under section 102 to the satisfaction of the court.

subsection.content: This section, as in force immediately before the commencement date* of the Patents (Amendment) Ordinance 2016 (17 of 2016), continues to apply to a patent the application for which is filed before that date. (Added 17 of 2016 s. 81)

section.name: s92
section.heading: Application for revocation

subsection.leadIn: An application for the revocation of a patent on the ground mentioned in section 91(1)(b)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: may be made only by a person found by the court in an action for a declaration or on a reference under section 55 to be entitled to be granted that patent or to be granted a patent for part of the matter comprised in the specification of the patent sought to be revoked, or in case more than one person is found to be so entitled, by all those persons; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: notwithstanding paragraph (a), may not be made if the action for a declaration was commenced or the reference under section 55 was made after the end of the period of 2 years beginning with the date of the grant of the patent sought to be revoked, unless it is shown that any person registered as a proprietor of the patent knew at the time of the grant or of the transfer of the patent to him that he was not entitled to the patent.

subsection.content: On an application for the revocation of a patent on the ground mentioned in section 91(1)(f), the court shall not make an order for revocation unless the proprietor of each patent has been allowed an opportunity of making observations and of amending the specification of the patent, and if the proprietors fail to satisfy the court that there are not 2 patents in respect of the same invention made by the same inventor, or to amend one or both specifications so as to prevent there being 2 patents in respect of the same invention made by the same inventor, the court shall revoke the patent having the shorter remaining period in force under section 39(1) or 126(1) (as may be appropriate) or, if both patents have the same remaining period in force, shall revoke any one of the patents. (Amended 17 of 2016 s. 82)

This section, as in force immediately before the commencement date* of the Patents (Amendment) Ordinance 2016 (17 of 2016), continues to apply to a patent the application for which is filed before that date. (Added 17 of 2016 s. 82)

section.name: s101
section.heading: Proceedings in which validity of patent may be put in issue

subsection.leadIn: Subject to the following provisions of this section, the validity of a patent may be put in issue—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: by way of defence, in proceedings for infringement of the patent under section 80 or, in the case of a standard patent, in proceedings under section 88 for infringement of rights conferred by the publication of an application;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in proceedings under section 89;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: in proceedings in which a declaration in relation to the patent is sought under section 90;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: in proceedings before the court under section 91 for the revocation of the patent;

paragraph.name: e
f
paragraph.content: in proceedings commenced under section 129(1)(b). (Added 17 of 2016 s. 85)

subsection.content: The validity of a patent may not be put in issue in any other proceedings and, in particular, no proceedings may be instituted (whether under this Ordinance or otherwise) seeking only a declaration as to the validity or invalidity of a patent.

The only grounds on which the validity of a patent may be put in issue (whether in proceedings for revocation under section 91 or otherwise) are the grounds on which the patent may be revoked under that section.

subsection.leadIn: No determination shall be made in any proceedings mentioned in subsection (1) on the validity of a patent which any person puts in issue on the ground mentioned in section 91(1)(b) unless—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: it has been determined—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: in entitlement proceedings commenced by that person; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: in the proceedings in which the validity of the patent is in issue,

paragraph.continued: that the patent should have been granted to him and not some other person; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: except in the case at paragraph (a)(i)—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: the proceedings in which the validity of the patent is in issue are commenced before the end of 2 years beginning with the date of the grant of the patent; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: it is shown that any person registered as a proprietor of the patent knew at the time of the grant or of the transfer of the patent to him that he was not entitled to the patent.

subsection.content: Where the validity of a patent is put in issue by way of defence or counterclaim the court shall, if it thinks it just to do so, give the defendant an opportunity to comply with the condition in subsection (4)(a).

subsection.def: In subsection (4) entitlement proceedings (享有權法律程序), in relation to a patent, means a reference under section 55(1) on the ground that the patent was granted to a person not entitled to it or proceedings for a declaration that it was so granted.

section.name: s101A
section.heading: Powers of court in validity proceedings in relation to short-term patents

subsection.content: Without limiting section 101, the court may, in any validity proceedings in relation to a short-term patent, exercise any of its powers under this section.

subsection.leadIn: If the short-term patent has not been subjected to a substantive examination, the court may—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: direct the proprietor of the patent to request the Registrar to carry out the examination; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: stay the proceedings pending the outcome of the examination.

subsection.leadIn: If the short-term patent is being subjected to a substantive examination, the court may—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: direct the examination to be suspended; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: stay the proceedings pending the outcome of the examination.

subsection.leadIn: If the substantive examination of a short-term patent has been suspended under subsection (3)(a), the court may, after the validity proceedings have been disposed of, order—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the examination to be resumed, on the conditions that the court thinks fit; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the examination to be terminated.

subsection.leadIn: In this section—
subsection.def: validity proceedings (有效性法律程序) means any proceedings in which the validity of a patent is put in issue under section 101(1).

part.name: P13
part.heading: General Provisions on Amendment of Patents and Patent Applications

section.name: s102
section.heading: Amendment of patent in infringement or revocation proceedings

subsection.content: In any proceedings before the court in which the validity of a patent is put in issue the court may, subject to section 103(3), allow the proprietor of the patent to amend the specification of the patent in such manner, and subject to such terms as to advertising the proposed amendment and as to costs, expenses or otherwise, as the court thinks fit. (Amended 17 of 2016 s. 88)

A person may give notice to the court of his opposition to an amendment proposed by the proprietor of the patent under this section, and if he does so the court shall notify the proprietor and consider the opposition in deciding whether the amendment or any amendment should be allowed.
An amendment of a specification of a patent under this section shall have effect and be deemed always to have had effect from the grant of the patent.

Rules of court may provide for the notification of any application under this section to the Registrar and for his appearance on the application and for giving effect to any order of the court on the application.

section.name: s103
section.heading: Amendments of applications and patents not to include added matter

subsection.leadIn: An application for a patent—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: which is made in respect of matter disclosed in an earlier application, or in the specification of a patent which has been granted; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: which discloses additional matter, that is, matter extending beyond that disclosed in the earlier application as filed, or the application for the patent as filed,

subsection.continued: is invalid to the extent that it extends the subject-matter disclosed in the earlier application as filed, or the application for the patent as filed.

subsection.content: Any amendment of an application for a patent is invalid to the extent that it extends the subject-matter disclosed in the application as filed.

subsection.leadIn: Any amendment of the specification of a patent is invalid to the extent that it— (Amended 17 of 2016 s. 89)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: extends the subject-matter disclosed in the application as filed; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: extends the protection conferred by the patent.

part.name: P14
part.heading: Language of Proceedings and Authentic Text

section.name: s104
section.heading: Language of proceedings before Registrar

subsection.content: An application for a patent must be filed in one of the official languages.

Except as otherwise provided in rules made for the purposes of this section, and notwithstanding section 5 of the Official Languages Ordinance (Cap. 5), the official language in which an application for a patent is filed shall be used as the language of the proceedings in all proceedings before the Registrar concerning the application or the resulting patent.

Where a designated patent application in respect of an invention is in one of the official languages, nothing in this section shall be construed as requiring an application for a standard patent (R) in respect of that invention to be filed in the same official language. (Amended 17 of 2016 s. 91)

subsection.leadIn: Rules may be made—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: requiring, in respect of any document filed or to be filed with the Registrar in proceedings under this Ordinance, the filing of a translation of the document into the language of the proceeding or into one or both official languages;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: providing for the use by any person in oral proceedings before the Registrar, of a language other than the language of the proceedings;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: in respect of documents to be used for the purpose of evidence in proceedings before the Registrar and which are in a language other than the language of the proceedings, providing for the filing of the document in that other language and the filing of a translation of the document into the language of the proceedings or into one of the official languages;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: in respect of information provided or to be provided to the Registrar and which is to be entered in the register, requiring the provision of that information in both official languages;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: specifying, in cases of entries which are made in the register in both official languages, which entry is to be authentic.

subsection.leadIn: Rules made for the purposes of subsection (4)(a) or (d)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: may specify periods within which translations of documents into the language of the proceedings or into the official languages are to be filed or within which information in the official languages is to be provided;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: may provide for extensions, upon application by a party to the proceedings, of such periods, and may require that applications for such extension shall be subject to the payment of a penalty fee.

section.name: s105
section.heading: Authentic text
section.content: Except as provided in section 106, the text of a patent or an application for a patent in the language of the proceedings before the Registrar shall be the authentic text in any proceedings before the Registrar or a court.

section.name: s106
section.heading: Authentic text of standard patent (R) and standard patent (R) application

subsection.content: Subject to subsection (2), the text of the specification of a corresponding designated patent or corresponding designated patent application in the language of the proceedings before the designated patent office shall be the authentic text of the specification of the standard patent (R) or standard patent (R) application respectively for the purposes of any proceedings under this Ordinance relating to the standard patent (R) or standard patent (R) application before the Registrar or a court. (Amended 17 of 2016 s. 92)

subsection.leadIn: If—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the language of the proceedings before the designated patent office is other than one of the official languages; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the corresponding designated patent or designated patent application as translated into one of the official languages confers protection which is narrower than that conferred by it in the language of the proceedings before the designated patent office,

subsection.continued: then a translation into one of the official languages of the specification of the corresponding designated patent or of the claims of the corresponding designated patent application shall be treated as the authentic text of the specification of the standard patent (R) or of the claims of the standard patent (R) application respectively for the purpose of any proceedings under this Ordinance, other than proceedings for the revocation of the patent. (Amended 17 of 2016 s. 92)

subsection.leadIn: If any translation such as is mentioned in subsection (2) results in a designated patent or designated patent application conferring the narrower protection, the proprietor of or applicant for the standard patent (R) may file a corrected translation with the Registrar and, if he pays the prescribed fee within the prescribed period, the Registrar shall publish it, but— (Amended 17 of 2016 s. 92)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: any payment for any use of the invention which (apart from section 69) would have infringed the patent as correctly translated, but not as originally translated, or in the case of an application would have infringed it as aforesaid if the patent had been granted, shall not be recoverable under that section;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the proprietor or applicant shall not be entitled to bring proceedings in respect of an act which infringed the patent as correctly translated, but not as originally translated, or in the case of an application would have infringed it as aforesaid if the patent has been granted,

subsection.continued: unless before that use or the doing of the act the corrected translation has been published by the Registrar or the proprietor or applicant has sent the corrected translation by post or delivered it to the public officer who made use or authorized the use of the invention or, as the case may be, to the person alleged to have done that act.

subsection.content: Where a correction of a translation is published under subsection (3) and before it is so published a person begins in good faith to do an act which would not constitute an infringement of the patent or application as originally translated but would (apart from section 69) constitute an infringement of it under the amended translation, or makes in good faith effective and serious preparations to do such an act, he shall have the rights conferred by section 41(4) and (5), and section 41(6) shall apply accordingly.

subsection.def: In this section language of the proceedings before the designated patent office (在指定專利當局進行的法律程序的語文), in relation to a corresponding designated patent or corresponding designated patent application, means the language in which proceedings relating to that patent or application are to be conducted before the designated patent office.

section.name: s107
section.heading: Amendment to patent or patent application to be in authentic text
section.content: An amendment to the specification of a patent or to an application for a patent may only be made in the language of the authentic text of the patent or application.

section.name: s108A
section.heading: Interpretation of Division 1 of Part 15
section.leadIn: In this Division—
section.def: Hong Kong application (香港申請) means a standard patent (O) application or short-term patent application;

non-Hong Kong application (非香港申請) means an application for a patent or other protection in or for a Paris Convention country or WTO member country, territory or area, other than a patent application under this Ordinance.

section.name: s109
section.heading: Non-prejudicial disclosure
section.leadIn: For the purposes of section 9B, a disclosure of an invention shall not be taken into consideration if it occurred no earlier than 6 months before the filing of the short-term patent application and if it was due to, or in consequence of— (Amended 17 of 2016 s. 97)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: an evident abuse in relation to the applicant or a proprietor of the invention for the time being; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the fact that the applicant or a proprietor of the invention for the time being had displayed the invention at an official, or officially recognized, international exhibition falling within the terms of the Convention on International Exhibitions signed at Paris on 22 November 1928 as applying to Hong Kong,

section.continued: but paragraph (b) shall apply only if the short-term patent application as filed contains a statement to the effect that the invention had been so displayed and contains the prescribed written evidence in support of the statement.

section.name: s110
section.heading: Priority right

subsection.leadIn: Subsection (1A) applies if a person has filed—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a non-Hong Kong application for an invention; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a Hong Kong application for an invention. (Replaced 17 of 2016 s. 99)

subsection.name: 1A
subsection.content: The person or the person’s successor in title enjoys, for the purpose of filing a subsequent short-term patent application for the same invention, a right of priority for the period of 12 months after the date of filing of the first non-Hong Kong application or Hong Kong application, subject to compliance with the prescribed conditions. (Added 17 of 2016 s. 99)

subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of subsection (1A)— (Amended 17 of 2016 s. 99)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: every filing of a non-Hong Kong application that is equivalent to a regular national filing under the domestic legislation of the place in or for which the application is filed, or under bilateral or multilateral agreements, is to be recognized as giving rise to a right of priority;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a subsequent non-Hong Kong application for the same subject-matter as in a previous first non-Hong Kong application and filed in or for the same place is to be considered as the first application for the purposes of determining priority if, and only if, at the date of filing the subsequent application, the previous application has been withdrawn, abandoned or refused, without being open to public inspection and without leaving any rights outstanding, and has not served as a basis for claiming a right of priority; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.leadIn: where pursuant to paragraph (b) a subsequent non-Hong Kong application is considered as a first application, the previous non-Hong Kong application may not later serve as a basis for claiming a right of priority,

subsection.continued: and in this subsection, regular national filing (正規國家提交) means any filing that establishes the date on which the application was filed, whatever may be the outcome of the application.

subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of subsection (1A)— (Amended 17 of 2016 s. 99)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: every regular filing of a Hong Kong application is to be recognized as giving rise to a right of priority in relation to other applications under this Part;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a subsequent Hong Kong application for the same subject-matter as in a previous first Hong Kong application is to be considered as the first application for the purposes of determining priority if, and only if, at the date of filing the subsequent application, the previous application has been withdrawn, abandoned or refused, without being open to public inspection and without leaving any rights outstanding, and has not served as a basis for claiming a right of priority; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: where pursuant to paragraph (b) a subsequent Hong Kong application is considered as a first application, the previous Hong Kong application may not later serve as a basis for claiming a right of priority,

subsection.continued: and in this subsection regular filing of a Hong Kong application (香港申請的正規提交) means any filing that establishes the date on which the Hong Kong application was filed, whatever may be the outcome of the application.

subsection.name: 3A
subsection.content: A right of priority that arises as a result of a non-Hong Kong application or Hong Kong application for an invention may be assigned or otherwise transmitted, either with the application or independently; and the reference in subsection (1A) to a person’s successor in title shall be construed accordingly. (Added 2 of 2001 s. 8)

section.name: s110A
section.heading: Restoration of priority right

subsection.leadIn: This section applies if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a person files a non-Hong Kong application or Hong Kong application for an invention; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the person or the person’s successor in title files a subsequent short-term patent application for the same invention within 2 months after the expiry of the 12-month period referred to in section 110(1A).

subsection.content: The applicant of the subsequent short-term patent application may apply to the Registrar for restoring the priority right of the patent application.

subsection.leadIn: The application for restoring the priority right (restoration application) must be made in the prescribed manner before the earlier of the following—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the end of 2 months after the expiry of the 12-month period;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the date on which preparations for publication under section 118(2) of the short-term patent granted because of the subsequent short-term patent application are completed.

subsection.content: A restoration application is to be regarded as being made only if the prescribed fee for the application is paid.

The Registrar may approve a restoration application if the Registrar is satisfied that the applicant failed to file the subsequent short-term patent application within the 12-month period even though the applicant had taken all reasonable care required by the circumstances.

section.name: s111
section.heading: Claiming priority

subsection.content: An applicant for a short-term patent desiring to take advantage of the priority of a previous application must file, in the prescribed manner and within the prescribed time, a statement of priority and a copy of the previous application. (Amended 17 of 2016 s. 101)

Multiple priorities may be claimed in respect of a short-term patent application, notwithstanding the fact that they originated in different countries, and where appropriate, multiple priorities may be claimed for any one claim.
Where multiple priorities are claimed, time limits which run from the date of priority shall run from the earliest date of priority.

If one or more priorities are claimed in respect of a short-term patent application, the right of priority shall cover only those elements of the short-term patent application which are included in the application or applications whose priority is claimed.

If certain elements of the invention for which priority is claimed do not appear among the claims formulated in the previous application, priority may nonetheless be granted if the documents of the previous application as a whole specifically disclosed such elements.

Subject to section 127C(3)(a), where a statement of priority is filed in accordance with this section, the applicant shall for the purpose of proceedings before the Registrar be deemed to be entitled to enjoy the right of priority shown in the statement. (Amended 17 of 2016 s. 101)

section.name: s112
section.heading: Effect of priority right

subsection.content: The right of priority shall have the effect that the date of priority of the previous application claimed under section 111 shall be regarded as being the date of priority of the short-term patent application for the purposes of this Ordinance. (Amended 17 of 2016 s. 102)

Where a short-term patent application is filed and the priority of a previous application is claimed under section 111, then, notwithstanding anything contained in this Ordinance, the short-term patent application and any short-term patent granted in pursuance of it shall not be invalidated by reason only of the fact that any subject-matter disclosed in the previous application was made available to the public at any time after the date of filing of the previous application.

section.name: s112A
section.heading: Application may be made alone or jointly

subsection.content: An application for a short-term patent for an invention may be made by a person alone or jointly with any other person.
For the purpose of proceedings before the Registrar, the applicant is to be regarded as being entitled to exercise the right to the short-term patent.

section.name: s113
section.heading: Requirements of short-term patent application

subsection.leadIn: A short-term patent application must—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: be signed by the applicant; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: be filed with the Registrar in the prescribed manner. (Replaced 17 of 2016 s. 105)

subsection.name: 1A
subsection.leadIn: A short-term patent application must contain—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a request for the grant of a short-term patent;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: a specification that provides for—

subparagraph.content: a description of the invention which is the subject of the application;
one or more claims but not exceeding 2 independent claims; and
any drawing referred to in the description or the claim or claims;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: an abstract;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: a search report in relation to the invention;

paragraph.name: e
f
paragraph.content: if the applicant desires to take advantage of the priority of a previous application, a statement of priority and a copy of the previous application required under section 111(1);

paragraph.name: g
paragraph.content: if applicable, a request for deferring the grant of a short-term patent under section 119; and

paragraph.name: h
paragraph.content: if the invention requires for its performance the use of a micro-organism, information on the availability of samples of the micro-organism to the public (if any). (Added 17 of 2016 s. 105)

subsection.leadIn: A short-term patent application—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: must state the name and address of the applicant;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: must—

subparagraph.content: identify each inventor of the invention; and
specify the last known address of each inventor (unless the inventor is also the applicant);

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: if the applicant is not an inventor, must contain a statement in the specified form indicating how the applicant becomes entitled to apply for a short-term patent for the invention; and

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: must specify an address in Hong Kong for service of documents. (Replaced 17 of 2016 s. 105)

subsection.content: Every such application shall also comply with the requirements of this Ordinance as to the provision of information in, or the translation of documents into, one or both official languages.

subsection.leadIn: Rules may— (Amended 17 of 2016 s. 105)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: provide that a short-term patent application shall or may contain a title of the invention and a designation of the classification of the invention; and (Amended 17 of 2016 s. 105)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: provide for the requirements of a short-term patent application for an invention that involves nucleotide and amino acid sequences. (Replaced 17 of 2016 s. 105)

subsection.content: A filing fee and an advertisement fee shall be payable within 1 month after the earliest filing with the Registrar of any part of the application, and if either fee is not paid within that period or the grace period provided in the rules, the application is to be regarded as being withdrawn. (Amended 17 of 2016 s. 105)
The foregoing provisions shall not prevent any application being initiated by documents complying with section 114(3). (Amended 17 of 2016 s. 105)

subsection.name: 7A
subsection.content: This section, as in force immediately before the commencement date* of the Patents (Amendment) Ordinance 2016 (17 of 2016), continues to apply to a short-term patent application filed with the Registrar before that date. (Added 17 of 2016 s. 105)

def.name: SearchReport
def.leadIn: In this section search report (查檢報告) means a report—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: by a prescribed searching authority of a search undertaken by that authority as to the prior art in relation to the invention, based on the claims and having due regard to the description and drawings (if any); and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: which contains the prescribed information.

section.name: s114
section.heading: Date of filing of short-term patent application

subsection.leadIn: For the purpose of according a date of filing to a short-term patent application, the Registrar must examine the application to ascertain—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: whether it complies with the requirement specified in subsection (3) (minimum requirement); and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: whether the prescribed filing fee and advertisement fee have been paid in due time.

subsection.content: Subject to section 114A(3), the date of filing of a short-term patent application is the earliest date on which the application complies with the minimum requirement.

subsection.leadIn: The requirement specified for subsection (1)(a) is that the documents filed for the short-term patent application contain—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: an indication that a short-term patent is sought;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: information identifying the applicant; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.leadIn: either one of the following—

subparagraph.content: something that appears to be a description of an invention;

a reference to an earlier specified application made by the applicant or the applicant’s predecessor in title, together with a statement indicating that a description and the drawings (if any) of the invention, which is the subject of the short-term patent application, are completely contained in the specified application.

subsection.content: If a date of filing cannot be accorded to a short-term patent application because of deficiencies in the application as regards the minimum requirement, the Registrar must give the applicant an opportunity to correct them in accordance with the rules.
If any deficiencies referred to in subsection (4) are not corrected within the prescribed time, the application must not be dealt with as a short-term patent application.

This section, as in force immediately before the commencement date* of the Patents (Amendment) Ordinance 2016 (17 of 2016), continues to apply to a short-term patent application filed with the Registrar before that date.

subsection.leadIn: In subsection (3)(c)(ii)—

def.name: SpecifiedApplication
def.leadIn: specified application (指明申請) means—

paragraph.name: a
b
paragraph.content: a standard patent (O) application; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: a short-term patent application.

section.name: s114A
section.heading: Filing of missing description or missing drawing

subsection.content: The Registrar may, by written notice, require the applicant of a short-term patent application to file a missing description or missing drawing in the prescribed manner and within the prescribed time.
The applicant may also, on the applicant’s own initiative, file a missing description or missing drawing in the prescribed manner and within the prescribed time.

If the short-term patent application has been accorded a date of filing in accordance with section 114(2), then on the filing of a missing description or missing drawing, the date of filing is to be changed to the date on which the description or drawing is filed.
The Registrar must, by written notice, inform the applicant of the change of the date of filing.

subsection.leadIn: Subsection (3) does not apply if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the applicant has claimed priority of a previous application under section 111;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the missing description or missing drawing is completely contained in the previous application;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: when filing the description or drawing, the applicant makes, in accordance with the rules, a request that the date of filing accorded in accordance with section 114(2) remains unchanged; and

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.leadIn: the applicant files within the prescribed time—

subparagraph.content: a copy of the previous application;
if the previous application is not in one of the official languages, its translation in one of the official languages; and
a statement indicating the location of the description or drawing in the previous application and, if applicable, in its translation.

subsection.leadIn: In this section—
subsection.def: missing description (欠交說明) means a part of the description of an invention referred to in section 113(1A)(b)(i), that has not been filed in a short-term patent application;
missing drawing (欠交繪圖) means a drawing referred to in section 113(1A)(b)(iii), that has not been filed in a short-term patent application.

section.name: s114B
section.heading: Missing description or missing drawing not filed or withdrawn

subsection.content: If any missing description or missing drawing as defined by section 114A(6) is not filed within the prescribed time under section 114A(1) or (2), any reference to the description or drawing in the specification contained in the short-term patent application under section 113(1A)(b) is to be regarded as being deleted.

If a notice of change of the date of filing is issued under section 114A(4), the applicant of the short-term patent application may, within 1 month after the date of the notice, withdraw the missing description or missing drawing that has been filed.

subsection.leadIn: On the withdrawal of the description or drawing—

paragraph.name: a
b
paragraph.content: the description or drawing is to be regarded as not having been filed; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the original date of filing of the patent application accorded in accordance with section 114(2) is to remain unchanged.

section.name: s115
section.heading: Examination as to formal requirements

subsection.content: If a short-term patent application has been accorded a date of filing, and is not regarded as being withdrawn under section 113(5), the Registrar must examine the application to ascertain whether the requirements of section 113 and of any rules made for the purposes of that section (formal requirements) have been complied with. (Amended 17 of 2016 s. 108)

subsection.name: 1A
subsection.content: If there are deficiencies in the application as regards the formal requirements that cannot be corrected, the application must be refused. (Added 17 of 2016 s. 108)

If there are deficiencies in the application as regards the formal requirements that may be corrected, the Registrar must give the applicant an opportunity to correct them in accordance with the rules. (Replaced 17 of 2016 s. 108)

subsection.leadIn: If any deficiencies referred to in subsection (2) are not corrected in accordance with the rules, then except as provided in subsection (4)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: where no steps are taken to correct the deficiencies, the application is to be regarded as being withdrawn; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in any other case, the application must be refused. (Replaced 17 of 2016 s. 108)

subsection.content: If a deficiency relating solely to a claim to any right of priority is not duly corrected, then only the right is lost for the application. (Amended 17 of 2016 s. 108)

section.name: s116
section.heading: Divisional short-term patent application
