section.leadIn: Where, after an application for a short-term patent has been filed and before the date under section 122 on which preparation for publication of the specification of the patent has been completed, a new application for a short-term patent is filed by the original applicant or his successor in title in accordance with the rules to be prescribed, being an application— (Amended 64 of 2000 s. 37)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: which is in respect of any part of the subject-matter contained in the earlier short-term patent application;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: which complies with the relevant requirements including procedures and time limits specified in the rules; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content:
which does not contravene section
103(1), (Amended 17 of 2016 s. 109)

section.continued: then such new application shall be treated as having, as its date of filing, the date of filing of the earlier short-term application and shall have the benefit of any right of priority.

section.name: s117
section.heading: Formality examination only
section.leadIn: Except as expressly provided to the contrary, nothing in this Part providing for the examination by the Registrar of an application for a short-term patent for an invention shall be construed as imposing any obligation upon the Registrar to consider or to have regard to, for the purpose of such examination, any question as to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the patentability of the invention;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: whether the applicant is entitled to any priority claimed in the application;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: whether the invention is properly disclosed in the application; or

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: any matter specified in section 9A, 9B, 9C, 9D, 9E, 9F, 77, 78, 79, 103, 109, 110, 111(2), (3), (4), (5) or (6) or 113(1A)(b)(ii). (Replaced 17 of 2016 s. 110)

division.name: D3
division.heading: Procedures up to and Including Grant

section.name: s118
section.heading: Grant of short-term patent and publication

subsection.content: If on examination by the Registrar under section 115(1) an application for a short-term patent is found to have satisfied the requirements of that provision, or if on a subsequent examination the deficiencies under section 115(2) are found to have been corrected in accordance with the rules, then as soon as practicable after such examination, but subject to sections 119 and 124, the Registrar shall grant a short-term patent for the invention. (Amended 17 of 2016 s. 112)

subsection.leadIn: As soon as practicable after a short-term patent has been granted under this section the Registrar shall—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: publish in the prescribed manner the specification of the short-term patent, the names of the proprietor and, if different, the inventor;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: issue a certificate of grant; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: advertise the fact of such grant by notice in the official journal. (Amended 2 of 2001 s. 14)

subsection.content: The Registrar may in any publication under subsection (2)(a) publish in addition to the matters specified in that subsection any other matters constituting or relating to the patent which in the Registrar’s opinion it is desirable to publish.

section.name: s119
section.heading: Deferral of grant of patent at applicant’s request

subsection.leadIn: Where in his application for a short-term patent an applicant has requested the Registrar to defer the grant of a patent for a period specified in the application, a short-term patent shall not be granted in that application until—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the expiry of that period, or of such shorter period as the applicant may subsequently specify by notice filed with the Registrar, after the date on which the requirements of section 115(1) are found to have been satisfied; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: 12 months after the date of filing of the application,

subsection.continued: whichever occurs first.

subsection.content: Where a request has been made under this section for the deferral of a grant, any grant under section 118(1) shall be made by the Registrar as soon as possible after the expiry of the period of deferral applying by virtue of this section.

section.name: s120
section.heading: Amendment of application for short-term patent before grant

subsection.content: Subject to this section and sections 122 and 103(2), at any time before a patent is granted under this Part an applicant may, in accordance with the prescribed conditions, amend the application of his own volition. (Amended 17 of 2016 s. 113)

The Registrar may, without an application being made to him for the purpose, amend the specification and abstract contained in an application for a short-term patent so as to acknowledge a registered trade mark.

section.name: s121
section.heading: Withdrawal of application

subsection.content: At any time before a short-term patent is granted the applicant may, subject to section 122, withdraw in writing his application and any such withdrawal may not be revoked.

subsection.leadIn: Where a short-term patent application is withdrawn under this section, or is regarded under this Ordinance to have been withdrawn, or is refused under any provision of this Ordinance, the following provisions shall apply— (Amended 17 of 2016 s. 114)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the applicant shall continue to enjoy, on the basis of the application, a right of priority under section 37C or 110 for filing a subsequent standard patent (O) application or short-term patent application; (Amended 17 of 2016 s. 114)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: no other right may be claimed under this Ordinance in relation to the application.

section.name: s122
section.heading: Limitation on withdrawal, amendment, etc. of application
section.content: No withdrawal of an application under section 121, no divisional application under section 116 nor any amendment under section 120 shall be allowed after the date on which preparations for publication under section 118(2) of the specification of a short-term patent to be granted in pursuance of the application have been completed.

section.name: s123
section.heading: Further processing of, and restoration of rights in respect of, short-term patent applications

subsection.content: Sections 28(1) and (2) and 29(1) and (2) apply, subject to necessary modification, to an application for a short-term patent as if a reference in those sections to an application or an applicant for a standard patent (R) and to Part 2 were a reference to an application or an applicant for a short-term patent and to this Part respectively.
Section 28 as applied by subsection (1) does not apply to a short-term patent application that is regarded as being withdrawn under section 113(5).
Section 29 as applied by subsection (1) does not apply in the case of a failure to comply with a time limit under section 110A, 111, 113, 114, 114A, 114B, 115, 116, 120 or 121.

This section, as in force immediately before the commencement date* of the Patents (Amendment) Ordinance 2016 (17 of 2016), continues to apply to a short-term patent application filed with the Registrar before that date. (Added 17 of 2016 s. 115)

section.name: s124
section.heading: Registrar may refuse to grant short-term patent
section.content: The Registrar may refuse to grant a short-term patent for an invention if he considers that the invention is not a patentable invention by reason of any of the matters specified in section 9A(5), and the Registrar shall give notice of any such refusal to the applicant.

section.name: s125
section.heading: Short-term patent application based on international application

subsection.content: Where an international application seeking a patent for invention or a patent for a utility model and designating the People’s Republic of China has entered its national phase in the People’s Republic of China, the applicant in the international application may apply for a short-term patent for the invention (if any) disclosed in that application. (Amended 17 of 2016 s. 117)

An application for a short-term patent made pursuant to this section may be filed at any time before a date 6 months after the entry into the national phase of the international application in the People’s Republic of China, or such other date as may be prescribed by rules.

subsection.leadIn: An application for a short-term patent made pursuant to this section shall contain—

paragraph.name: a
b
paragraph.content: a photocopy of the international search report in relation to the international application as published under Article 21(3) of the Patent Cooperation Treaty (whether contained in the international application as published or separately published);

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the date of entry of the international application into the national phase in the People’s Republic of China;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: a photocopy of the translation of the international application (if any) published by the China National Intellectual Property Administration; and (Amended 2 of 2001 s. 9; 21 of 2024 s. 43)

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: a photocopy of any information that may be published by the China National Intellectual Property Administration concerning the international application. (Amended 2 of 2001 s. 9; 21 of 2024 s. 43)

subsection.content: Section 113 applies in relation to an application for a short-term patent made pursuant to this section as if for subsection (1A)(b) to (d) of that section there was substituted a reference to the documents specified in subsection (3)(a) to (e) of this section. (Amended 17 of 2016 s. 117)

Where an application made pursuant to this section results in the grant of a short-term patent, the application shall be deemed to have as its date of filing the international filing date accorded to the international application for the purposes of Article 11 of the Patent Cooperation Treaty and, in this Ordinance, reference to the date of filing of an application in relation to a short-term patent which has been granted pursuant to an application made as provided for in this section shall be construed accordingly.

subsection.leadIn: In this section—
subsection.def: China National Intellectual Property Administration (國家知識產權局) means the China National Intellectual Property Administration established under the laws of the People’s Republic of China the functions of which include the granting of patents for inventions and patents for utility models. (Replaced 21 of 2024 s. 43)

division.name: D4
division.heading: Provisions on Short-term Patents after Grant

section.name: s126
section.heading: Term of short-term patent

subsection.leadIn: A short-term patent granted under this Part—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: shall take effect on the date on which the fact of its grant is advertised in the official journal; and (Amended 2 of 2001 s. 14)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: subject to subsections (2) and (3), shall remain in force until the end of the period of 8 years beginning with the date of filing the application for the patent. (Amended E.R. 4 of 2020)

subsection.content: If it is desired to keep a short-term patent in force for a further 4 years after the expiry of the 4th year from the date of filing of the application for that patent, the prescribed renewal fee shall be paid within the 3 months ending with the expiry of that 4th year, and a short-term patent shall cease to have effect at the expiry of that 4th year if the renewal fee is not so paid.

subsection.leadIn: Despite subsection (2), where the date of grant of a short-term patent occurs after the expiry of the 4th year from the date of filing of the application for that patent then—

paragraph.name: a
b
paragraph.content: the patent shall cease to have effect under this section if, and only if, the prescribed renewal fee is not paid as provided in paragraph (a).

subsection.content: The Registrar may by regulation amend the period specified in subsection (2) as being the period ending with the expiry of the 4th year from the date of filing of the short-term patent application.

subsection.leadIn: If within 6 months after the end of the period specified in subsection (2) or (3), as the case may be, the renewal fee and any prescribed additional fee is paid, the short-term patent shall be treated as if it had never expired, and accordingly—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: anything done under or in relation to it during that further period shall be valid;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: an act which would constitute an infringement of it if it had not expired shall constitute such an infringement; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: an act which would constitute Government use of the patented invention if the patent had not expired shall constitute that use.

subsection.leadIn: The Chief Executive in Council may by regulation amend— (Amended 22 of 1999 s. 3)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the period specified in subsection (1)(b) as being the period for which a short-term patent shall remain in force;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the period specified in subsection (2) or (3) by reference to which a short-term patent, if not renewed, shall cease to have effect.

section.name: s126A
section.heading: Observations by third parties on patentability of short-term patents

subsection.content: After a short-term patent for an invention has been granted, any person may file with the Registrar a written notice of the person’s observations on the patentability of the invention.

subsection.leadIn: The notice must—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: set out the observations and the grounds for the observations; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: be filed in the prescribed manner and within the prescribed time.

subsection.content: The Registrar must, as soon as practicable after receiving a notice under subsection (1), send a copy of the notice to the proprietor of the short-term patent.

If the short-term patent is being subjected to a substantive examination, the Registrar must consider the observations when deciding whether to issue a certificate of substantive examination in respect of the patent.
A person does not become a party to any proceedings under this Ordinance only because the person files a notice under subsection (1).

section.name: s127
section.heading: Restoration of lapsed short-term patents
section.content: Sections 40 and 41 shall apply to short-term patents, with necessary modification, as if reference in those sections to a standard patent and to section 39 were a reference to a short-term patent and to section 126 respectively.

section.name: s127A
section.heading: Interpretation of Division 5 of Part 15
section.leadIn: In this Division—
section.def: examination requirement (審查規定) means a requirement specified in section 127C(2);

def.name: UnfulfilledRequirement
def.leadIn: unfulfilled requirement (不獲符合的規定), for a short-term patent, means an examination requirement that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in the Registrar’s opinion, is not complied with by the patent; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: is set out in the notice to the proprietor of the patent under section 127D(2).

section.name: s127B
section.heading: Request for substantive examination of short-term patents

subsection.leadIn: The proprietor of a short-term patent may—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: request the Registrar to carry out a substantive examination of the patent; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: subject to section 103(3), file a request to amend the specification of the patent at the same time.

subsection.leadIn: Any other person may also request the Registrar to carry out a substantive examination of the patent if the person satisfies the Registrar that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: there are reasonable grounds to suspect that the invention, which is the subject of the patent—

subparagraph.content: is not new;
lacks an inventive step; or
is not susceptible of industrial application; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: because of the person’s legitimate business interests, it would be reasonable for the examination to be carried out.

subsection.leadIn: A request for substantive examination of a short-term patent must—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: be made in the prescribed manner; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: be accompanied by the prescribed fee.

subsection.leadIn: No request for substantive examination of a short-term patent may be made if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: a previous request for substantive examination of the patent has been made, and—

subparagraph.content: the outcome of the substantive examination is still pending; or
that request has resulted in the issue of a certificate of substantive examination of the patent or in the revocation of the patent; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the patent has been found by the court to be wholly valid in any proceedings in which the validity of the patent is contested.

subsection.content: A request for substantive examination of a short-term patent may not be withdrawn.

section.name: s127C
section.heading: Substantive examination by Registrar

subsection.content: On receiving a request for substantive examination of a short-term patent, the Registrar must examine the patent and consider any requested amendment filed under section 127B(1)(b) to determine whether the patent, together with the amendment (if allowed), complies with all the requirements specified in subsection (2).

subsection.leadIn: The requirements are—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the invention, which is the subject of the patent, is patentable under section 9A;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the specification of the patent discloses the invention in accordance with section 77;

paragraph.name: c
d
paragraph.content: all the claims contained in the specification comply with the requirements of section 78(1);

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.leadIn: the matter disclosed in the specification of the patent does not extend beyond that disclosed in—

subparagraph.content: the patent application as filed; and
if the patent was granted because of a specified new application, the earlier short-term patent application as filed;

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: the protection conferred by the patent has not been extended by an amendment to its specification;

paragraph.name: g
paragraph.leadIn: the patent is not one of 2 patents that—

subparagraph.content: are granted for the same invention made by the same inventor; and
have the same material date.

subsection.leadIn: In examining a short-term patent to determine whether the patent complies with the requirement specified in subsection (2)(a), the Registrar must have regard to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: if a claim for priority of a previous application has been made in respect of the patent application under section 111, whether the applicant is entitled to the priority claimed; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if a missing description or missing drawing as defined by section 114A(6) has been filed, whether the date of filing of the patent application remains unchanged.

subsection.content: The Registrar must carry out the examination in accordance with the rules.

subsection.leadIn: In subsection (2)(e)(ii)—

def.name: SpecifiedNewApplication
def.leadIn: specified new application (指明新申請) means—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a new short-term patent application made in accordance with an order under section 55(4); or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a new short-term patent application referred to in section 116.

section.name: s127D
section.heading: Proprietor may file representations and requests for amendment, etc.

subsection.content: If the Registrar is of the opinion that a short-term patent, together with any requested amendment under section 127B(1)(b) (if allowed), does not comply with any examination requirement, the Registrar must, by written notice, inform the proprietor of the patent of the opinion.
The notice must set out each examination requirement that, in the Registrar’s opinion, is not complied with by the patent.

subsection.leadIn: The proprietor may respond to the notice by filing, in accordance with the rules, any or all of the following—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a representation to establish that the patent complies with an unfulfilled requirement;

paragraph.name: b
c
paragraph.content: a request to review the Registrar’s opinion.

section.name: s127E
section.heading: Registrar must consider representations and requests for amendment, etc.

subsection.leadIn: The Registrar must, in accordance with the rules—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: consider and decide—

subparagraph.content: whether a representation filed under section 127D(3)(a) establishes that a short-term patent complies with an unfulfilled requirement; and
whether a requested amendment filed under section 127D(3)(b), if allowed, would enable the patent to comply with an unfulfilled requirement; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: review the Registrar’s opinion on a request filed under section 127D(3)(c).

subsection.leadIn: If the Registrar is of the opinion that a requested amendment filed under section 127B(1)(b) or 127D(3)(b), if allowed, would enable the patent to comply with an unfulfilled requirement, the Registrar must, in accordance with the rules—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: publish the requested amendment;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: consider any opposition to the amendment filed by third parties; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: decide whether to allow the amendment.

subsection.content: If the Registrar thinks fit, the Registrar may refer the opposition proceedings to the court, and the court may allow the amendment by order, subject to any conditions that it thinks fit.

subsection.leadIn: If the requested amendment filed under section 127B(1)(b) or 127D(3)(b) is allowed by the Registrar or the court, the Registrar must, in accordance with the rules—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: record and publish the amendment; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: advertise the fact of the publication by notice in the official journal.

subsection.content: An amendment to the specification of a patent allowed under this section has effect as from the grant of the patent.

section.name: s127F
section.heading: Certificate of substantive examination

subsection.leadIn: The Registrar must issue a certificate of substantive examination in respect of a short-term patent, if the Registrar—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: has examined the patent and considered any requested amendment filed under section 127B(1)(b);

paragraph.name: b
c
paragraph.content: is of the opinion that the patent, together with any amendment allowed under section 127E, complies with all the examination requirements.

subsection.leadIn: As soon as practicable after the certificate is issued, the Registrar must—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: inform the following persons by written notice that the certificate has been issued—

subparagraph.content: the proprietor of the patent; and
the person who has requested the substantive examination (if that person is not the proprietor);

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: send the certificate to the proprietor; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: enter a record of the issue of the certificate in the register.

section.name: s127G
section.heading: Revocation of short-term patents

subsection.leadIn: The Registrar must revoke a short-term patent if the Registrar—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: has examined the patent and considered any requested amendment filed under section 127B(1)(b);

paragraph.name: b
c
paragraph.content: is of the opinion that the patent, together with any amendment allowed under section 127E, does not comply with all the examination requirements.

subsection.leadIn: As soon as practicable after the patent is revoked, the Registrar must—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: inform the following persons by written notice that the patent has been revoked—

subparagraph.content: the proprietor of the patent; and
the person who has requested the substantive examination (if that person is not the proprietor);

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: advertise the fact of the revocation by notice in the official journal; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: enter a record of the revocation in the register.

section.name: s129
section.heading: Court proceedings in relation to short-term patents

subsection.leadIn: The proprietor of a short-term patent may only commence proceedings before a court for the enforcement of rights conferred under this Ordinance in relation to the patent (enforcement proceedings) if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a certificate of substantive examination has been issued in respect of the patent;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a request for substantive examination of the patent has been made under section 127B and the examination has not been terminated by a court order under section 101A(4)(b); or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.leadIn: a certificate has been granted by a court under section 84(1), certifying the court’s finding that—

subparagraph.content: the patent is wholly valid; or
if the enforcement proceedings relate to a relevant respect of the patent, the patent is valid in that respect. (Added 17 of 2016 s. 123)

subsection.leadIn: In any enforcement proceedings—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: it is for the proprietor of the short-term patent to establish the validity of the patent or a relevant respect of the patent (as the case requires), and the fact that the patent has been granted is of no account in that regard; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: in the absence of evidence to the contrary, any of the following is sufficient proof of the validity of the patent or a relevant respect of the patent—

subparagraph.content: the certificate of substantive examination of the patent;
a certificate referred to in subsection (1)(c);
any evidence which is sufficient to establish prima facie the validity of the patent or that respect of the patent (as the case requires). (Replaced 17 of 2016 s. 123)

subsection.content: In any enforcement proceedings, an application by the proprietor of the short-term patent for an injunction under section 80(1)(a) in interlocutory proceedings must be accompanied by a certificate or evidence referred to in subsection (2)(b)(i), (ii) or (iii). (Added 17 of 2016 s. 123)

If, in enforcement proceedings, an order is made in interlocutory proceedings granting or refusing an application for an injunction under section 80(1)(a) or an order under section 80(1)(b), any party may apply to the court for an order that the matter proceed to early trial and, subject to compliance by that party with rules of court, the court shall so order unless it considers that the interests of justice would not be served by the making of such an order. (Amended 17 of 2016 s. 123)

subsection.leadIn: A court making an order for an early trial under subsection (4)— (Amended 17 of 2016 s. 123)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: may also make such order as respects the period before trial as the justice of the case requires;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: shall by the order determine the mode of trial.

subsection.content: This section, as in force immediately before the commencement date* of the Patents (Amendment) Ordinance 2016 (17 of 2016), continues to apply to enforcement proceedings commenced before that date. (Added 17 of 2016 s. 123)

section.name: s130
section.heading: Appeal from Registrar

subsection.def: Except as otherwise expressly provided by rules, an appeal to the court shall lie from any decision or order of the Registrar under this Ordinance, and for the purposes of this provision decision (決定) includes any act of the Registrar in exercise of a discretion vested in him by or under this Ordinance.

subsection.content: Any appeal under this Ordinance which concerns a patent application which has not been published shall be heard in private.

subsection.leadIn: In any appeal under this Ordinance—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the Registrar shall be entitled to appear or be represented and be heard in support of his decision or order;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the Registrar shall appear if so directed by the court.

subsection.content: In any appeal under this Ordinance the court may exercise any power which could have been exercised by the Registrar in proceedings from which the appeal is brought.

section.name: s131
section.heading: Registrar’s appearance in proceedings involving register

subsection.content: In any proceedings before the court involving an application for the alteration or rectification of the register, the Registrar shall be entitled to appear or be represented and be heard, and shall appear if so directed by the court.

subsection.leadIn: Unless otherwise directed by the court, the Registrar may instead of appearing submit to the court a statement in writing signed by him, giving particulars of—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: any proceedings before him in relation to the matter in issue;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the grounds of any decision given by him affecting it;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the practice of the registry in like cases; or

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: such matters relevant to the issues and within his knowledge as Registrar as he thinks fit,

subsection.continued: and the statement shall be deemed to form part of the evidence in the proceedings.

section.name: s132
section.heading: General powers of the court

subsection.content: The court may, for the purpose of determining any question in the exercise of its original or appellate jurisdiction under this Ordinance, make any order or exercise any other power which the Registrar could have made or exercised for the purpose of determining that question.
Every order of the court shall be subject to appeal to the Court of Appeal.

section.name: s133
section.heading: Procedure in case of option to apply to court or Registrar

subsection.leadIn: Where under this Ordinance an applicant has an option to make an application either to the court or to the Registrar—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: if an action concerning the patent or application for a patent in question is pending, the application must be made to the court;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if in any other case the application is made to the Registrar, the Registrar may, at any stage of the proceedings, refer the application to the court, or he may, after hearing the parties, determine the question between them, subject to appeal to the court.

subsection.content: Subsection (1) is without prejudice to the court’s powers, apart from this section, to determine any question referred to in that subsection.
Reference in subsection (1) to an option to make an application either to the court or to the Registrar includes reference to an option to refer a question either to the court or to the Registrar.

section.name: s134
section.heading: Burden of proof in certain cases

subsection.content: If the invention for which a patent is granted is a process for obtaining a new product, the same product produced by a person other than the proprietor of the patent or a licensee of his shall, unless the contrary is proved, be taken in any proceedings to have been obtained by that process.

In considering whether a party has discharged the burden imposed upon him by this section, the court shall not require him to disclose any manufacturing or commercial secrets if it appears to the court that it would be unreasonable to do so.

section.name: s135
section.heading: Exercise of Registrar’s discretionary powers
section.content: Without prejudice to any rule of law, the Registrar shall give any party to a proceeding before him an opportunity of being heard before exercising adversely to that party any discretion vested in the Registrar by this Ordinance or by the rules.

section.name: s136
section.heading: Costs and expenses in proceedings before court

subsection.content: Subject to subsection (2), in all proceedings before the court under this Ordinance the court may award to any party such costs as it may consider reasonable. (Amended 2 of 2001 s. 10)

In proceedings before the court under section 58 the court shall, in determining whether to award costs or expenses to any party and what costs or expenses to award, have regard to all the relevant circumstances, including the financial position of the parties.

If in any such proceedings the court directs that any costs of one party shall be paid by another party, the court may settle the amount of the costs by fixing a lump sum or may direct that the costs shall be taxed on a scale specified by the court, being a scale of costs prescribed by rules of court.

section.name: s137
section.heading: Costs and expenses in proceedings before Registrar

subsection.content: The Registrar may, in proceedings before him under this Ordinance, by order award to any party such costs as he may consider reasonable and direct how and by what parties they are to be paid.
Any costs awarded under this section shall, if the court so orders, be recoverable by execution issued from the court as if they were payable under an order of that court.

Rules may empower the Registrar, in such cases as may be prescribed, to require a party to proceedings before him to give security for costs, in relation to those proceedings or to proceedings on appeal, and may provide for the consequences if security is not given.

section.name: s138
section.heading: Licences granted by order of the court or Registrar or by Director of Health

subsection.content: Any order for the grant of a licence under section 14, 37K, 56, 64 or 65 shall, without prejudice to any other method of enforcement, have effect as if it were a deed, executed by the proprietor of the standard patent and all other necessary parties, granting a licence in accordance with the order. (Amended 21 of 2007 s. 6; 17 of 2016 s. 125)

Without prejudice to any other method of enforcement, any import compulsory licence or export compulsory licence granted under section 72C or 72M (as the case may be) has effect as if it were a deed, executed by the proprietor of the standard patent or the short-term patent (as the case may be) and all other necessary parties. (Added 21 of 2007 s. 6)

section.name: s139
section.heading: Immunity of Registrar as regards official acts
section.leadIn: Neither the Registrar nor any officer of his—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: shall be taken to warrant the validity of any patent granted under this Ordinance; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: shall incur any liability by reason of or in connection with any examination or investigation required or authorized by this Ordinance, or any report or other proceedings consequent on any such examination or investigation.

section.name: s139A
section.heading: Protection of Government and public officers

subsection.leadIn: No liability shall rest on the Government or any public officer by reason of the fact that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: any authority is given under section 69; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: any import compulsory licence or export compulsory licence is granted under section 72C or 72M (as the case may be).

subsection.content: A public officer is not personally liable in respect of any act or omission of his if it was done or made by him in the honest belief that it was required or authorized in the exercise of any function, duty or power of his under Part 9, 9A or 9B (as the case may be). (Amended 17 of 2016 s. 126)
The protection conferred on public officers by subsection (2) in respect of any act or omission does not affect any liability of the Government in tort for that act or omission.

section.name: s140
section.heading: Recognition of agents

subsection.content: Subject to this section and to the rules, where under this Ordinance any act has to be done by or to any person in connection with a patent or any procedure relating to a patent or the obtaining of a patent, the act may be done by or to an agent of such person duly authorized by that person orally or in writing.

A person duly authorized by another person under subsection (1) to act as his agent may (subject to any provision to the contrary in any agreement between the agent and that person), on giving notice to the Registrar and the other person, cease to act as agent for the other person.
Rules may authorize the Registrar to refuse to recognize as agent in respect of any business under this Ordinance any person specified for the purpose in the rules.
The Registrar shall refuse to recognize as an agent a person who neither resides nor has a place of business in Hong Kong.

section.name: s141
section.heading: Falsification of register, etc.
section.leadIn: A person who—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: makes or causes to be made a false entry in any register kept under this Ordinance, knowing the entry to be false; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: makes or causes to be made a writing falsely purporting to be a copy or reproduction of an entry in any register kept under this Ordinance, or produces or tenders or causes to be produced or tendered in evidence any such writing, knowing the writing to be false,

section.continued: commits an offence and is liable—

paragraph.name: i
paragraph.content: on summary conviction, to a fine at level 5 and to imprisonment for 6 months;

paragraph.name: ii
paragraph.content: on conviction on indictment, to imprisonment for 2 years.

section.name: s142
section.heading: Unauthorized claim of patent rights

subsection.content: Subject to this section, a person who falsely represents that anything disposed of by him for value is a patented product commits an offence and is liable on summary conviction to a fine at level 3.

For the purposes of subsection (1), a person who for value disposes of an article having stamped, engraved or impressed on it or otherwise applied to it the word “patent” or “patented” or “專利” or “享有專利” or anything expressing or implying that the article is a patented product, shall be taken to represent that the article is a patented product.

Subsection (1) does not apply where the representation is made in respect of a product after the patent for that product or, as the case may be, the process in question has expired or been revoked and before the end of a period which is reasonably sufficient to enable the accused to take steps to ensure that the representation is not made (or does not continue to be made).
In proceedings for an offence under this section it shall be a defence for the accused to prove that he used due diligence to prevent the commission of the offence.

section.name: s143
section.heading: Unauthorized claim that patent has been applied for

subsection.leadIn: Subject to this section, a person who represents that a patent has been applied for in respect of any article disposed of for value by him when in fact—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: no such application for a patent has been made; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: any such application has been refused, withdrawn or deemed withdrawn, (Amended 17 of 2016 s. 128)

subsection.continued: commits an offence and is liable on summary conviction to a fine at level 3.

subsection.content: Subsection (1)(b) does not apply where the representation is made (or continues to be made) before the expiry of a period which begins with the refusal, withdrawal or deemed withdrawal and which is reasonably sufficient to enable the accused to take steps to ensure that the representation is not made (or does not continue to be made). (Amended 17 of 2016 s. 128)

For the purposes of subsection (1), a person who for value disposes of an article having stamped, engraved or impressed on it or otherwise applied to it the words “patent applied for” or “patent pending” or “已申請專利” or “專利申請待決”, or anything expressing or implying that an application has been made for a patent in respect of the article, shall be taken to represent that an application for such a patent has been made.
In any proceedings for an offence under this section it shall be a defence for the accused to prove that he used due diligence to prevent the commission of such an offence.

section.name: s144
section.heading: Misuse of title “Patents Registry”
section.content: A person who uses on his place of business, or any document issued by him, or otherwise, the words “Patents Registry” or “專利註冊處” or any other words suggesting that his place of business is, or is officially connected with, the Patents Registry, commits an offence and is liable on summary conviction to a fine at level 4.

section.name: s144A
section.heading: Prohibition on use of certain titles and descriptions

subsection.content: A person must not, in the course of or in connection with the person’s business, trade or profession in Hong Kong, knowingly use or permit the use of a title or description specified in subsection (2).

subsection.leadIn: The title or description is—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: certified patent agent;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: registered patent agent;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: certified patent attorney;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: registered patent attorney; or

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.leadIn: a title or description which may reasonably cause anyone to believe that the person using or permitted to use the title or description holds a qualification—

subparagraph.content: that is specifically granted for approving that person to provide patent agency services in Hong Kong; and
that is recognized by law or endorsed by the Government.

subsection.leadIn: Subsection (1) does not prohibit a person from using, or from permitting the use of, a title or description that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: solely relates to the person’s qualification for lawfully providing patent agency services in a jurisdiction outside Hong Kong; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: clearly indicates the jurisdiction.

subsection.content: A person who contravenes subsection (1) commits an offence and is liable on conviction to a fine of $500,000.

section.name: s145
section.heading: Offences by corporations or partners

subsection.content: Where an offense under this Ordinance committed by a body corporate is proved to have been committed with the consent or connivance of, or to be attributable to any neglect on the part of, a director, manager, secretary or other similar officer of the body, or a person purporting to act in any such capacity, he as well as the body corporate is guilty of the offence and liable to be proceeded against and punished accordingly.

subsection.leadIn: The following provisions apply for the purposes of proceedings for an offence under this Ordinance alleged to have been committed by a body corporate—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: any rules of court relating to the service of documents;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: section 19A (plea by a corporation before a magistrate) and section 87 (procedure on charge of indictable offence against corporation) of the Magistrates Ordinance (Cap. 227).

subsection.content: Where the affairs of a body corporate are managed by its members, subsection (1) shall apply in relation to the acts and defaults of a member in connection with his functions of management as if he were a director of the body corporate.

Where a partnership is guilty of an offence under this Ordinance, every partner, other than a partner who is proved to have been ignorant of or to have attempted to prevent the commission of the offence, is also guilty of the offence and liable to be proceeded against and punished accordingly.

Without prejudice to any liability of the partners under subsection (4), proceedings for an offence under this Ordinance alleged to have been committed by a partnership shall be brought against the partnership in the name of the firm and not in that of the partners.
A fine imposed on a partnership on its conviction in such proceedings shall be paid out of the partnership assets.

Where an offence under this Ordinance committed by a partner in a firm is proved to have been committed with the consent or connivance of, or to be attributable to any neglect on the part of, any other partner in the firm or any person concerned in the management of the firm, that partner or the person concerned in the management of the firm is also guilty of the offence and liable to be proceeded against and punished accordingly.

section.name: s146
section.heading: Correction of errors in patents and applications

subsection.content: The Registrar may, subject to the rules, correct any error of translation or transcription, clerical error or mistake in any specification of a patent or application for a patent or any document filed in connection with a patent or such an application.

Where the Registrar is requested to correct such an error or mistake any person may in accordance with the rules give the Registrar notice of opposition to the request and the Registrar shall determine the matter.

section.name: s147
section.heading: Information about patent applications and patents, and inspection of documents

subsection.content: After publication of an application for a standard patent in accordance with section 20 or 37Q or the grant of a short-term patent the Registrar shall upon the filing of a written request in the prescribed manner give the person making the request such information, and permit him to inspect such documents, relating to the application or any patent granted in pursuance of the application or to the short-term patent as may be specified in the request, subject, however, to any prescribed restrictions. (Amended 17 of 2016 s. 131)

Subject to this section, until an application for a standard patent is so published or a short-term patent is granted documents or information constituting or relating to the application for the standard patent or the short-term patent shall not, without the consent of the proprietor or the applicant (as the case may be), be published or communicated to any person by the Registrar.

Subsection (2) shall not prevent the Registrar from publishing or communicating to others any prescribed bibliographic information about an unpublished application for a standard patent or an application for a short-term patent.

Where a person is notified that an application for a standard patent has been made, but not published in accordance with section 20 or 37Q (as the case requires), and that the applicant will, if the patent is granted, bring proceedings against that person in the event of his doing an act specified in the notification after the application is so published, that person may make a request under subsection (1), notwithstanding that the application has not been published, and that subsection shall apply accordingly. (Amended 17 of 2016 s. 131)

Where a person is notified that an application for a short-term patent has been made and that the applicant will, if the patent is granted, bring proceedings against that person in the event of his doing an act specified in the notification, that person may make a request under subsection (1) and that subsection shall apply accordingly.

Where an application for a standard patent is filed, but not published, and a new application for a standard patent is filed in respect of any part of the subject-matter of the earlier application (either in accordance with the rules or in pursuance of an order under section 13 or 37J) and is published, any person may make a request under subsection (1) in the prescribed manner relating to the earlier application and the Registrar shall give him such information and permit him to inspect such documents as could have been given or inspected if the earlier application had been published. (Amended 17 of 2016 s. 131)

section.name: s148
section.heading: Hours of business and excluded days

subsection.content: The Registrar may, by notice published in the official journal, give directions specifying the hours of business of the registry for the purpose of the transaction by the public of business under this Ordinance, and the days which are business days for that purpose. (Amended 2 of 2001 s. 14)

Business done on any day after the specified hours of business, or on a day which is not a business day, shall be deemed to have been done on the next business day; and where the time for doing anything under this Ordinance expires on a day which is not a business day, that time shall be extended to the next business day.
Directions made under this section may make different provision for different classes of business.

section.name: s149
section.heading: Rules

subsection.leadIn: The Registrar may make rules—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: for the purposes of any provision of this Ordinance authorizing the making of rules (other than rules of court) with respect to any matter; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: for prescribing anything authorized or required by an provision of this Ordinance to be prescribed,

subsection.continued: and generally for regulating practice and procedure under this Ordinance.

subsection.leadIn: Without limiting subsection (1), rules may make provision— (Amended 17 of 2016 s. 132)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: in connection with applications for patents and other documents which may be filed with the Registrar—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: prescribing the form and contents of any such documents;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: requiring copies of such documents to be furnished;

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: prescribing the manner of filing of such documents;

paragraph.name: b
c
d
e
f
paragraph.content: providing for the appointment of advisers to assist the Registrar in any proceedings before him;

paragraph.name: g
paragraph.content: prescribing time limits for doing anything required to be done in connection with any such proceeding by this Ordinance or the rules and providing for the alteration of any period of time specified in this Ordinance or the rules;

paragraph.name: h
paragraph.content: giving effect to the right of an inventor of an invention to be mentioned in an application for a patent for the invention;

paragraph.name: i
paragraph.content: without prejudice to any other provision of this Ordinance, requiring and regulating the translation of documents in connection with a patent or an application for a patent into the language of the proceedings or into one or both official languages and the filing and verification of any such translations;

paragraph.name: j
paragraph.content: providing for the publication and sale of documents by the registry and of information about such documents;

paragraph.name: k
paragraph.content: prescribing opposition or revocation proceedings in designated patent offices for the purposes of sections 43 and 44.

subsection.name: 2A
subsection.leadIn: Without limiting subsection (1), the rules may, in relation to an invention that requires for its performance the use of a micro-organism—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: provide for the manner in which information on the availability of samples of the micro-organism to the public (if any) is to be contained in a standard patent (O) application or a short-term patent application for the invention;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: provide for the circumstances under which the patent application or the specification of the patent granted is to be regarded as having disclosed the invention in a manner sufficiently clear and complete for the invention to be performed by a person skilled in the art;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.leadIn: require the applicant for or proprietor of the patent—

subparagraph.content: to take specified steps to make the samples available to the public; and
not to impose or maintain restrictions on the use of the samples, unless expressly provided otherwise; and

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: provide for the circumstances under which the samples need only be made available to a person or a description of persons. (Added 17 of 2016 s. 132)

subsection.content: Rules may make different provision for different cases.

subsection.leadIn: Rules made under this section—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: authorizing the rectification of irregularities of procedure; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: providing for the alteration of any period of time,

subsection.continued: may authorize the extension or further extension of any period of time notwithstanding that the period has already expired.

subsection.content: Rules prescribing fees, including any penalty fee under section 104(5)(b), shall not be made except with the consent of the Financial Secretary.

subsection.leadIn: Any rules made under subsection (2)(c) may—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: prescribe fees fixed at; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: provide for fees to be fixed at,

subsection.continued: levels that provide for the recovery of expenditure incurred or likely to be incurred by the Government or other authority in the exercise of any or all functions under this Ordinance, and shall not be limited by reference to the amount of administrative or other costs incurred or likely to be incurred in the exercise of any particular function.

subsection.content: Rules may provide for arrangements to be made by the Registrar for the publication of reports of cases relating to patents decided by the Registrar and of cases relating to patents (whether under this Ordinance or otherwise) decided by any court or body (whether in Hong Kong or elsewhere).

section.name: s150
section.heading: Registrar may specify forms to be used

subsection.content: The Registrar may require the use of such forms as he may, by notice published in the official journal, specify in connection with the granting of a patent or any other proceeding before him under this Ordinance. (Amended 2 of 2001 s. 14)
A notice under subsection (1) may contain any direction of the Registrar with respect to the use of a form specified in the notice.

A notice published under subsection (1) shall not be regarded as subsidiary legislation for the purpose of section 34 of the Interpretation and General Clauses Ordinance (Cap. 1). (Added 2 of 2001 s. 11)

section.name: s150A
section.heading: Power to specify official journal, etc.

subsection.content: The Registrar may from time to time, by notice published in the Gazette, specify a publication to be the official journal of record for the purposes of this Ordinance, with effect as of the date specified in the notice.

Where a publication is specified under subsection (1), every notice, request, document or other matter required by this Ordinance or the rules to be published in the official journal shall, from the effective date specified in the notice, be published in the publication so specified, and any reference in this Ordinance or the rules to the official journal shall be construed accordingly.

The Registrar may publish or cause to be published a journal in which there may be published such documents and information relating to a patent or an application for a patent as the Registrar thinks fit.
For the avoidance of doubt, the Registrar may specify the Gazette or the journal referred to in subsection (3) to be the official journal of record.
A publication specified under subsection (1) and the journal referred to in subsection (3) need not be in a documentary form.
A notice published under subsection (1) shall not be regarded as subsidiary legislation for the purpose of section 34 of the Interpretation and General Clauses Ordinance (Cap. 1).

section.name: s151
section.heading: Application
section.content: Subject to the provisions of this Ordinance, and notwithstanding section 5(3) of the Crown Proceedings Ordinance (Cap. 300), this Ordinance applies to the Government and the Offices set up by the Central People’s Government in the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region.

section.name: s152
section.heading: Forfeited articles
section.content: Nothing in this Ordinance affects the right of the Government or any person deriving title directly or indirectly from the Government to dispose of or use articles forfeited under the law relating to customs or excise.

section.name: s153
section.heading: Amendment of Schedule 1
section.leadIn: The Chief Executive in Council may by order published in the Gazette— (Amended 22 of 1999 s. 3)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: add to Schedule 1 the name of—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: any country which has acceded to the Paris Convention;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: any country, territory or area which has acceded to the World Trade Organisation Agreement;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: delete from the Schedule 1 the name of—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: any country which has denounced the Paris Convention;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: any country, territory or area which has denounced the World Trade Organisation Agreement; and (Amended 2 of 2001 s. 13)

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: otherwise amend Schedule 1. (Added 2 of 2001 s. 13)

section.name: s154
section.heading: Repeal

subsection.content: The Registration of Patents Ordinance (Cap. 42) is repealed.
The repeal effected by subsection (1) is subject to the following provisions of this Part.

section.name: s155
section.heading: Validity of instruments made or things done under the repealed Ordinance
section.content: Insofar as any instrument made or other thing done at any time under any provision of the repealed Ordinance could have been made or done under a corresponding provision of this Ordinance it shall not be invalidated by the repeals made by this Ordinance but shall have effect as if made or done under that corresponding provision.

section.name: s159
section.heading: Interpretation (Part 19)

subsection.leadIn: In this Part, unless the context otherwise requires—
subsection.def: the repealed Ordinance (已廢除條例) means the Registration of Patents Ordinance (Cap. 42).

subsection.leadIn: In this Part, unless the context otherwise requires—

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a reference to the repealed Ordinance is a reference to that Ordinance as it applied immediately before the commencement date. (Amended 31 of 2025 s. 144)
